impact of outcome reporting bias in randomised controlled trials on a cohort of systematic reviews","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0066844","date":"2013-05-09","title":"Systematic Review of the Empirical Evidence of Study Publication Bias and Outcome Reporting Bias  An Updated Review","abstract":"Background\nThe increased use of meta-analysis in systematic reviews of healthcare interventions has highlighted several types of bias that can arise during the completion of a randomised controlled trial.\n\n Study publication bias and outcome reporting bias have been recognised as a potential threat to the validity of meta-analysis and can make the readily available evidence unreliable for decision making.\n\n\nMethodology/Principal Findings\nIn this update, we review and summarise the evidence from cohort studies that have assessed study publication bias or outcome reporting bias in randomised controlled trials.\n\n Twenty studies were eligible of which four were newly identified in this update.\n\n Only two followed the cohort all the way through from protocol approval to information regarding publication of outcomes.\n\n Fifteen of the studies investigated study publication bias and five investigated outcome reporting bias.\n\n Three studies have found that statistically significant outcomes had a higher odds of being fully reported compared to non-significant outcomes (range of odds ratios: 2.2 to 4.7).\n\n In comparing trial publications to protocols, we found that 4062% of studies had at least one primary outcome that was changed, introduced, or omitted.\n\n We decided not to undertake meta-analysis due to the differences between studies.\n\n\nConclusions\nThis update does not change the conclusions of the review in which 16 studies were included.\n\n Direct empirical evidence for the existence of study publication bias and outcome reporting bias is shown.\n\n There is strong evidence of an association between significant results and publication; studies that report positive or significant results are more likely to be published and outcomes that are statistically significant have higher odds of being fully reported.\n\n Publications have been found to be inconsistent with their protocols.\n\n Researchers need to be aware of the problems of both types of bias and efforts should be concentrated on improving the reporting of trials.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3702538","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0020185","date":"2011-04-27","title":"Epidemiology, Quality and Reporting Characteristics of Systematic Reviews of Traditional Chinese Medicine Interventions Published in Chinese Journals","abstract":"Background\nSystematic reviews (SRs) of TCM have become increasingly popular in China and have been published in large numbers.\n\n This review provides the first examination of epidemiological characteristics of these SRs as well as compliance with the PRISMA and AMSTAR guidelines.\n\n\nObjectives\nTo examine epidemiological and reporting characteristics as well as methodological quality of SRs of TCM published in Chinese journals.\n\n\nMethods\nFour Chinese databases were searched (CBM, CSJD, CJFD and Wanfang Database) for SRs of TCM, from inception through Dec 2009. Data were extracted into Excel spreadsheets.\n\n The PRISMA and AMSTAR checklists were used to assess reporting characteristics and methodological quality, respectively.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 369 SRs were identified, most (97.6%) of which used the terms systematic review or meta-analysis in the title.\n\n None of the reviews had been updated.\n\n Half (49.8%) were written by clinicians and nearly half (47.7%) were reported in specialty journals.\n\n The impact factors of 45.8% of the journals published in were zero.\n\n The most commonly treated conditions were diseases of the circulatory and digestive disease.\n\n Funding sources were not reported for any reviews.\n\n Most (68.8%) reported information about quality assessment, while less than half (43.6%) reported assessing for publication bias.\n\n Statistical mistakes appeared in one-third (29.3%) of reviews and most (91.9%) did not report on conflict of interest.\n\n\nConclusions\nWhile many SRs of TCM interventions have been published in Chinese journals, the quality of these reviews is troubling.\n\n As a potential key source of information for clinicians and researchers, not only were many of these reviews incomplete, some contained mistakes or were misleading.\n\n Focusing on improving the quality of SRs of TCM, rather than continuing to publish them in great quantity, is urgently needed in order to increase the value of these studies.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3102106","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of Science","authors":[{"firstname":"Bin","surname":"Ma","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jiwu","surname":"Guo","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Guoqing","surname":"Qi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Haimin","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jiye","surname":"Peng","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Yulong","surname":"Zhang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Yanqin","surname":"Ding","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Kehu","surname":"Yang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Lisa","surname":"Hartling","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Lisa","surname":"Hartling","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pmed.0040078","date":"2007-01-08","title":"Epidemiology and Reporting Characteristics of Systematic Reviews","abstract":"Background\nSystematic reviews (SRs) have become increasingly popular to a wide range of stakeholders.\n\n We set out to capture a representative cross-sectional sample of published SRs and examine them in terms of a broad range of epidemiological, descriptive, and reporting characteristics, including emerging aspects not previously examined.\n\n\nMethods and Findings\nWe searched Medline for SRs indexed during November 2004 and written in English.\n\n Citations were screened and those meeting our inclusion criteria were retained.\n\n Data were collected using a 51-item data collection form designed to assess the epidemiological and reporting details and the bias-related aspects of the reviews.\n\n The data were analyzed descriptively.\n\n In total 300 SRs were identified, suggesting a current annual publication rate of about 2,500, involving more than 33,700 separate studies including one-third of a million participants.\n\n The majority (272 [90.7%]) of SRs were reported in specialty journals.\n\n Most reviews (213 [71.0%]) were categorized as therapeutic, and included a median of 16 studies involving 1,112 participants.\n\n Funding sources were not reported in more than one-third (122 [40.7%]) of the reviews.\n\n Reviews typically searched a median of three electronic databases and two other sources, although only about two-thirds (208 [69.3%]) of them reported the years searched.\n\n Most (197/295 [66.8%]) reviews reported information about quality assessment, while few (68/294 [23.1%]) reported assessing for publication bias.\n\n A little over half (161/300 [53.7%]) of the SRs reported combining their results statistically, of which most (147/161 [91.3%]) assessed for consistency across studies.\n\n Few (53 [17.7%]) SRs reported being updates of previously completed reviews.\n\n No review had a registration number.\n\n Only half (150 [50.0%]) of the reviews used the term systematic review or meta-analysis in the title or abstract.\n\n There were large differences between Cochrane reviews and non-Cochrane reviews in the quality of reporting several characteristics.\n\n\nConclusions\nSRs are now produced in large numbers, and our data suggest that the quality of their reporting is inconsistent.\n\n This situation might be improved if more widely agreed upon evidence-based reporting guidelines were endorsed and adhered to by authors and journals.\n\n These results substantiate the view that readers should not accept SRs uncritically.\n\n\n","id":"PMC1831728","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of international registry of systematic-review protocols","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/2046-4053-1-2","date":"2012-02-09","title":"The nuts and bolts of PROSPERO: an international prospective register of systematic reviews","abstract":"Background\nFollowing publication of the PRISMA statement, the UK Centre for Reviews and Dissemination (CRD) at the University of York in England began to develop an international prospective register of systematic reviews with health-related outcomes.\n\n The objectives were to reduce unplanned duplication of reviews and provide transparency in the review process, with the aim of minimizing reporting bias.\n\n\nMethods\nAn international advisory group was formed and a consultation undertaken to establish the key items necessary for inclusion in the register and to gather views on various aspects of functionality.\n\n This article describes the development of the register, now called PROSPERO, and the process of registration.\n\n\nResults\nPROSPERO offers free registration and free public access to a unique prospective register of systematic reviews across all areas of health from all around the world.\n\n The dedicated web-based interface is electronically searchable and available to all prospective registrants.\n\n At the moment, inclusion in PROSPERO is restricted to systematic reviews of the effects of interventions and strategies to prevent, diagnose, treat, and monitor health conditions, for which there is a health-related outcome.\n\n\nConclusions\nThere has been international support and an enthusiastic response to the principle of prospective registration of protocols for systematic reviews and to the development of PROSPERO.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3348673","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed Central","authors":[{"firstname":"Alison","surname":"Booth","email":"alison.booth@york.ac.uk","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Mike","surname":"Clarke","email":"m.clarke@qub.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Gordon","surname":"Dooley","email":"Gordon@metaxis.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Davina","surname":"Ghersi","email":"davina.ghersi@nhmrc.gov.au","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"David","surname":"Moher","email":"dmoher@ohri.ca","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Mark","surname":"Petticrew","email":"Mark.Petticrew@lshtm.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Lesley","surname":"Stewart","email":"lesley.stewart@york.ac.uk","contributions":"3"}]},{"doi":"10.1186/2046-4053-1-60","date":"2012-11-12","title":"Does use of the CONSORT Statement impact the completeness of reporting of randomised controlled trials published in medical journals? A Cochrane review<sup>a</sup>","abstract":"Background\nThe Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials (CONSORT) Statement is intended to facilitate better reporting of randomised clinical trials (RCTs).\n\n A systematic review recently published in the Cochrane Library assesses whether journal endorsement of CONSORT impacts the completeness of reporting of RCTs; those findings are summarised here.\n\n\nMethods\nEvaluations assessing the completeness of reporting of RCTs based on any of 27 outcomes formulated based on the 1996 or 2001 CONSORT checklists were included; two primary comparisons were evaluated.\n\n The 27 outcomes were: the 22 items of the 2001 CONSORT checklist, four sub-items describing blinding and a total summary score of aggregate items, as reported.\n\n Relative risks (RR) and 99% confidence intervals were calculated to determine effect estimates for each outcome across evaluations.\n\n\nResults\nFifty-three reports describing 50 evaluations of 16,604 RCTs were assessed for adherence to at least one of 27 outcomes.\n\n Sixty-nine of 81 meta-analyses show relative benefit from CONSORT endorsement on completeness of reporting.\n\n Between endorsing and non-endorsing journals, 25 outcomes are improved with CONSORT endorsement, five of these significantly (? = 0.01).\n\n The number of evaluations per meta-analysis was often low with substantial heterogeneity; validity was assessed as low or unclear for many evaluations.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe results of this review suggest that journal endorsement of CONSORT may benefit the completeness of reporting of RCTs they publish.\n\n No evidence suggests that endorsement hinders the completeness of RCT reporting.\n\n However, despite relative improvements when CONSORT is endorsed by journals, the completeness of reporting of trials remains sub-optimal.\n\n Journals are not sending a clear message about endorsement to authors submitting manuscripts for publication.\n\n As such, fidelity of endorsement as an intervention has been weak to date.\n\n Journals need to take further action regarding their endorsement and implementation of CONSORT to facilitate accurate, transparent and complete reporting of trials.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3564748","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0001577","date":"2008-01-08","title":"A Systematic Evaluation of the Impact of STRICTA and CONSORT Recommendations on Quality of Reporting for Acupuncture Trials","abstract":"Background\nWe investigated whether there had been an improvement in quality of reporting for randomised controlled trials of acupuncture since the publication of the STRICTA and CONSORT statements.\n\n We conducted a before-and-after study, comparing ratings for quality of reporting following the publication of both STRICTA and CONSORT recommendations.\n\n\nMethodology and Principal Findings\nNinety peer reviewed journal articles reporting the results of acupuncture trials were selected at random from a wider sample frame of 266 papers.\n\n Papers published in three distinct time periods (19941995, 19992000 and 20042005) were compared.\n\n Assessment criteria were developed directly from CONSORT and STRICTA checklists.\n\n Papers were independently assessed for quality of reporting by two assessors, one of whom was blind to information which could have introduced systematic bias (e.\n\ng.\n\n date of publication).\n\n We detected a statistically significant increase in the reporting of CONSORT items for papers published in each time period measured.\n\n We did not, however, find a difference between the number of STRICTA items reported in journal articles published before and 3 to 4 years following the introduction of STRICTA recommendations.\n\n\nConclusions and Significance\nThe results of this study suggest that general standards of reporting for acupuncture trials have significantly improved since the introduction of the CONSORT statement in 1996, but that quality in reporting details specific to acupuncture interventions has yet to change following the more recent introduction of STRICTA recommendations.\n\n Wider targeting and revision of the guidelines is recommended.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2216683","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of Science","authors":[{"firstname":"Stephanie report does not necessarily mean the trial is a good one, but at least the reader can make a judgement.\n Clear reporting is a pre-requisite for judgement of study quality.\n The CONSORT statement evolves as empirical research moves on.\n CONSORT 2010 is even clearer than before and includes some new items with a particular emphasis on selective reporting of outcomes.\n The challenge is for G.","surname":"Altman","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0027319","date":"2011-10-13","title":"Establishing a Minimum Dataset for Prospective Registration of Systematic Reviews: An International Consultation","abstract":"Background\nIn response to growing recognition of the value of prospective registration of systematic review protocols, we planned to develop a web-based open access international register.\n\n In order for the register to fulfil its aims of reducing unplanned duplication, reducing publication bias, and providing greater transparency, it was important to ensure the appropriate data were collected.\n\n We therefore undertook a consultation process with experts in the field to identify a minimum dataset for registration.\n\n\nMethods and Findings\nA two-round electronic modified Delphi survey design was used.\n\n The international panel surveyed included experts from areas relevant to systematic review including commissioners, clinical and academic researchers, methodologists, statisticians, information specialists, journal editors and users of systematic reviews.\n\n Direct invitations to participate were sent out to 315 people in the first round and 322 in the second round.\n\n Responses to an open invitation to participate were collected separately.\n\n There were 194 (143 invited and 51 open) respondents with a 100% completion rate in the first round and 209 (169 invited and 40 open) respondents with a 91% completion rate in the second round.\n\n In the second round, 113 (54%) of the participants reported having previously taken part in the first round.\n\n Participants were asked to indicate whether a series of potential items should be designated as optional or required registration items, or should not be included in the register.\n\n After the second round, a 70% or greater agreement was reached on the designation of 30 of 36 items.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe results of the Delphi exercise have established a dataset of 22 required items for the prospective registration of systematic reviews, and 18 optional items.\n\n The dataset captures the key attributes of review design as well as the administrative details necessary for registration.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3217945","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of of the CONSORT Statement by high impact factor medical journals: a survey of journal editors and journal 'Instructions to Authors'","abstract":"Background\nThe CONSORT Statement provides recommendations for reporting randomized controlled trials.\n\n We assessed the extent to which leading medical journals that publish reports of randomized trials incorporate the CONSORT recommendations into their journal and editorial processes.\n\n\nMethods\nThis article reports on two observational studies.\n\n Study 1: We examined the online version of 'Instructions to Authors' for 165 high impact factor medical journals and extracted all text mentioning the CONSORT Statement or CONSORT extension papers.\n\n Any mention of the International Committee of Medical Journal Editors (ICMJE) or clinical trial registration were also sought and extracted.\n\n Study 2: We surveyed the editor-in-chief, or editorial office, for each of the 165 journals about their journal's endorsement of CONSORT recommendations and its incorporation into their editorial and peer-review processes.\n\n\nResults\nStudy 1: Thirty-eight percent (62/165) of journals mentioned the CONSORT Statement in their online 'Instructions to Authors'; of these 37% (23/62) stated this was a requirement, 63% (39/62) were less clear in their recommendations.\n\n Very few journals mentioned the CONSORT extension papers.\n\n Journals that referred to CONSORT were more likely to refer to ICMJE guidelines (RR 2.16; 95% CI 1.51 to 3.08) and clinical trial registration (RR 3.67; 95% CI 2.36 to 5.71) than those journals which did not.\n\n\nConclusion\nJournals should be more explicit in their recommendations and expectations of authors regarding the CONSORT Statement and related CONSORT F","surname":"Schulz","email":"kshulz@fhi.org","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0035621","date":"2012-03-21","title":"Are Peer Reviewers Encouraged to Use Reporting Guidelines? A Survey of 116 Health Research Journals","abstract":"Background\nPre-publication peer review of manuscripts should enhance the value of research publications to readers who may wish to utilize findings in clinical care or health policy-making.\n\n Much published research across all medical specialties is not useful, may be misleading, wasteful and even harmful.\n\n Reporting guidelines are tools that in addition to helping authors prepare better manuscripts may help peer reviewers in assessing them.\n\n We examined journals' instructions to peer reviewers to see if and how reviewers are encouraged to use them.\n\n\nMethods\nWe surveyed websites of 116 journals from the McMaster list.\n\n Main outcomes were 1) identification of online instructions to peer reviewers and 2) presence or absence of key domains within instructions: on journal logistics, reviewer etiquette and addressing manuscript content (11 domains).\n\n\nFindings\nOnly 41/116 journals (35%) provided online instructions.\n\n All 41 guided reviewers about the logistics of their review processes, 38 (93%) outlined standards of behaviour expected and 39 (95%) contained instruction about evaluating the manuscript content.\n\n There was great variation in explicit instruction for reviewers about how to evaluate manuscript content.\n\n Almost half of the online instructions 19/41 (46%) mentioned reporting guidelines usually as general statements suggesting they may be useful or asking whether authors had followed them rather than clear instructions about how to use them.\n\n All 19 named CONSORT for reporting randomized trials but there was little mention of CONSORT extensions.\n\n PRISMA, QUOROM (forerunner of PRISMA), STARD, STROBE and MOOSE were mentioned by several journals.\n\n No other reporting guideline was mentioned by more than two journals.\n\n\nConclusions\nAlthough almost half of instructions mentioned reporting guidelines, their value in improving research publications is not being fully realised.\n\n Journals have a responsibility to support peer reviewers.\n\n We make several recommendations including wider reference to the EQUATOR Network online library (www.\n\nequator-network.\n\norg/).\n\n\n","id":"PMC3338712","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of systematic review of the use of theory in the design of guideline dissemination and implementation strategies and interpretation of the results of rigorous evaluations","abstract":"Background\nThere is growing interest in the use of cognitive, behavioural, and organisational theories in implementation research.\n\n However, the extent of use of theory in implementation research is uncertain.\n\n\nMethods\nWe conducted a systematic review of use of theory in 235 rigorous evaluations of guideline dissemination and implementation studies published between 1966 and 1998. Use of theory was classified according to type of use (explicitly theory based, some conceptual basis, and theoretical construct used) and stage of use (choice/design of intervention, process/mediators/moderators, and post hoc/explanation).\n\n\nResults\nFifty-three of 235 studies (22.5%) were judged to have employed theories, including 14 studies that explicitly used theory.\n\n The majority of studies (n = 42) used only one theory; the maximum number of theories employed by any study was three.\n\n Twenty-five different theories were used.\n\n A small number of theories accounted for the majority of theory use including PRECEDE (Predisposing, Reinforcing, and Enabling Constructs in Educational Diagnosis and Evaluation), diffusion of innovations, information overload and social marketing (academic detailing).\n\n\nConclusions\nThere was poor justification of choice of intervention and use of theory in implementation research in the identified studies until at least 1998. Future research should explicitly identify the justification for the interventions.\n\n Greater use of explicit theory to understand barriers, design interventions, and explore mediating pathways and moderators is needed to advance the science of implementation research.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2832624","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed factors in two large Indian cities.\n Cross-sectional interview data were collected from 1,076 non-HIV patients in multiple healthcare settings in Mumbai and Bengaluru, India.\n The vast majority of A prospective study of physicians on a medical service","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Universal precautions in the era of HIV/AIDS: Perception of health service providers in Yunnan, China","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]}]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"HIV and AIDS awareness: an evaluation of a short training programme for midwives","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[],"References depth 2":[]},{"doi":"10.7448/IAS.16.1.17981","date":"2012-12-05","title":"Are integrated HIV services less stigmatizing than stand-alone models of care? A comparative case study from Swaziland","abstract":"Introduction\nIntegrating HIV with primary health services has the potential to reduce HIV-related stigma through delivering care in settings disassociated with HIV.\n\n This study investigated the relationship between integrated care and felt stigma.\n\n The study design was a comparative case study of four models of HIV care in Swaziland, ranging from fully integrated to fully stand-alone HIV care.\n\n\nMethods\nAn exit survey (N=602) measured differences in felt stigma across model of care; the primary outcome perception of HIV status exposure through clinic attendance was analyzed using multivariable logistic regression.\n\n In-depth interviews (N=22) explored whether and how measured differences in stigma experiences were related to service integration.\n\n\nResults\nThere were significant differences in perceived status exposure across models of care.\n\n After adjustment for potential confounding between sites, those at a partially integrated site and a partially stand-alone site had greater odds of perceived status exposure than those at the fully stand-alone site (aOR 3.33, 95% CI 1.985.60; and aOR 11.84, 95% CI 6.8920.36, respectively).\n\n There was no difference between the fully stand-alone and the fully integrated clinic.\n\n Qualitative data suggested that many clients at HIV-only sites felt greater confidentiality knowing that those around them were positive, and support was gained from other HIV care clients.\n\n Confidentiality was maintained in various ways, even in stand-alone sites, through separate waiting areas for HIV testing and HIV treatment, and careful clinic and room labelling.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe relationship between model of care and stigma was complex, and the hypothesis that stigma is higher at stand-alone sites did not hold true in this high prevalence setting.\n\n Policy-makers should ensure that service integration does not increase stigma, in particular within partially integrated models of care.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3545202","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"International AIDS Society","authors":[{"firstname":"Kathryn","surname":"Church","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Alison","surname":"Wringe","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Phelele","surname":"Fakudze","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Joshua","surname":"Kikuvi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Dudu","surname":"Simelane","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Susannah diasporic women","abstract":"Introduction\nLiterature indicates that racism, sexism, homophobia and HIV-related stigma have adverse impacts on health, well-being, and quality of life among HIV-positive women of African descent (African/Black diaspora).\n\n However, limited evidence exists on the effectiveness of interventions aimed at reducing stigma tailored for these women.\n\n This study systematically reviewed randomized controlled trials (RCTs), non-randomized observational and quasi-experimental studies evaluating the effectiveness of interventions aimed at reducing stigma experienced by this population.\n\n\nMethods\nThe Cochrane methodology was used to develop a search strategy in consultation with a librarian scientist.\n\n Databases searched included the Cochrane Library, Ovid EMBASE, PsycInfo, and 10 others.\n\n Two reviewers independently assessed the studies for potential relevance and conducted the Cochrane grading of RCTs to assess risk of bias and the NewcastleOttawa scale to assess the quality of non-randomized studies.\n\n Eligible papers were selected if they employed an intervention design with African/Black diasporic women living with HIV as the target population and had a primary outcome of stigma reduction.\n\n\nResults\nOf the five studies that met all of the eligibility criteria, four demonstrated the effectiveness of interventions in reducing HIV-related stigma.\n\n Only two of the five studies were designed specifically for HIV-positive African/Black diasporic women.\n\n Limitations included the absence of interventions addressing other forms of stigma and discrimination (e.\n\ng.\n\n gender discrimination, racism, heterosexism).\n\n\nConclusions\nOur findings suggest that there are limited interventions designed to address multiple forms of stigma, including gender and racial discrimination, experienced by HIV-positive African/Black diasporic women.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4393416","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"International AIDS found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1472-6963-7-205","date":"2007-12-18","title":"'I believe that the staff have reduced their closeness to patients': an exploratory study on the impact of HIV/AIDS on staff in four rural hospitals in Uganda","abstract":"Background\nStaff shortages could harm the provision and quality of health care in Uganda, so staff retention and motivation are crucial.\n\n Understanding the impact of HIV/AIDS on staff contributes to designing appropriate retention and motivation strategies.\n\n This research aimed 'to identify the influence of HIV/AIDS on staff working in general hospitals at district level in rural areas and to explore support required and offered to deal with HIV/AIDS in the workplace'.\n\n Its results were to inform strategies to mitigate the impact of HIV/AIDS on hospital staff.\n\n\nMethods\nA cross-sectional study with qualitative and quantitative components was implemented during two weeks in September 2005. Data were collected in two government and two faith-based private not-for-profit hospitals purposively selected in rural districts in Uganda's Central Region.\n\n Researchers interviewed 237 people using a structured questionnaire and held four focus group discussions and 44 in-depth interviews.\n\n\nResults\nHIV/AIDS places both physical and, to some extent, emotional demands on health workers.\n\n Eighty-six per cent of respondents reported an increased workload, with 48 per cent regularly working overtime, while 83 per cent feared infection at work, and 36 per cent reported suffering an injury in the previous year.\n\n HIV-positive staff remained in hiding, and most staff did not want to get tested as they feared stigmatization.\n\n Organizational responses were implemented haphazardly and were limited to providing protective materials and the HIV/AIDS-related services offered to patients.\n\n Although most staff felt motivated to work, not being motivated was associated with a lack of daily supervision, a lack of awareness on the availability of HIV/AIDS counselling, using antiretrovirals and working overtime.\n\n The specific hospital context influenced staff perceptions and experiences.\n\n\nConclusion\nHIV/AIDS is a crucially important contextual factor, impacting on working conditions in various ways.\n\n Therefore, organizational responses should be integrated into responses to other problematic working conditions and adapted to the local context.\n\n Opportunities already exist, such as better use of supervision, educational sessions and staff meetings.\n\n However, exchanges on interventions to improve staff motivation and address HIV/AIDS in the health sector are urgently required, including information on results and details of the context and implementation process.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2244629","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pmed.0020246","date":"2005-06-13","title":"Discriminatory Attitudes and Practices by Health Workers toward Patients with HIV/AIDS in Nigeria","abstract":"Background\nNigeria has an estimated 3.6 million people with HIV/AIDS and is home to one out of every 11 people with HIV/AIDS worldwide.\n\n This study is the first population-based assessment of discrimination against people living with HIV/AIDS in the health sector of a country.\n\n The purpose of this study was to characterize the nature and extent of discriminatory practices and attitudes in the health sector and indicate possible contributing factors and intervention strategies.\n\n The study involved a cross-sectional survey of 1,021 Nigerian health-care professionals (including 324 physicians, 541 nurses, and 133 midwives identified by profession) in 111 health-care facilities in four Nigerian states.\n\n\nMethods and Findings\nFifty-four percent of the health-care professionals (550/1,021) were sampled from public tertiary care facilities.\n\n Nine percent of professionals reported refusing to care for an HIV/AIDS patient, and 9% indicated that they had refused an HIV/AIDS patient admission to a hospital.\n\n Fifty-nine percent agreed that people with HIV/AIDS should be on a separate ward, and 40% believed a person's HIV status could be determined by his or her appearance.\n\n Ninety-one percent agreed that staff and health-care professionals should be informed when a patient is HIV-positive so they can protect themselves.\n\n Forty percent believed that health-care professionals with HIV/AIDS should not be allowed to work in any area of health-care that requires patient contact.\n\n Twenty percent agreed that many with HIV/AIDS behaved immorally and deserve the disease.\n\n Basic materials needed for treatment and prevention of HIV were not adequately available.\n\n Twelve percent agreed that treatment of opportunistic infections in HIV/AIDS patients wastes resources, and 8% indicated that treating someone with HIV/AIDS is a waste of precious resources.\n\n Providers who reported working in facilities that did not always practice universal precautions were more likely to favor restrictive policies toward people with HIV/AIDS.\n\n Providers who reported less adequate training in HIV treatment and ethics were also more likely to report negative attitudes toward patients with HIV/AIDS.\n\n There was no consistent pattern of differences in negative attitudes and practices across the different health specialties surveyed.\n\n\nConclusion\nWhile most health-care professionals surveyed reported being in compliance with their ethical obligations despite the lack of resources, discriminatory behavior and attitudes toward patients with HIV/AIDS exist among a significant proportion of health-care professionals in the surveyed states.\n\n Inadequate education about HIV/AIDS and a lack of protective and treatment materials appear to contribute to these practices and attitudes.\n\n\n","id":"PMC1176239","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of through training of health professionals in China","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]}]},{"doi":"10.1017/gmh.2015.17","date":"2015-07-19","title":"Improving mental health among people living with HIV: a review of intervention trials in low- and middle-income countries","abstract":"People living with HIV (PLWH) experience greater psychological distress than the general population.\n Evidence from high-incomes countries suggests that psychological interventions for PLWH can improve mental health symptoms, quality of life, and HIV care engagement.\n However, little is known about the effectiveness of mental health interventions for PLWH in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), where the large majority of PLWH reside.\n This systematized review aims to synthesize findings from mental health intervention trials with PLWH in LMICs to inform the delivery of mental health services in these settings.\n A systematic search strategy was undertaken to identify peer-reviewed published papers of intervention trials addressing negative psychological states or disorders (e.\ng.\n depression, anxiety) among PLWH in LMIC settings.\n Search results were assessed against pre-established inclusion and exclusion criteria.\n Data from papers meeting criteria were extracted for synthesis.\n Twenty-six papers, published between 2000 and 2014, describing 22 unique interventions were identified.\n Trials were implemented in sub-Saharan Africa (n = 13), Asia (n = 7), and the Middle East (n = 2), and addressed mental health using a variety of approaches, including cognitive-behavioral (n = 18), family-level (n = 2), and pharmacological (n = 2) treatments.\n Four randomized controlled trials reported significant intervention effects in mental health outcomes, and 11 preliminary studies demonstrated promising findings.\n Among the limited mental health intervention trials with PLWH in LMICs, few demonstrated efficacy.\n Mental health interventions for PLWH in LMICs must be further Peer Mentors to Support South African Women Living with HIV and Their Infants","abstract":"Objective\nWe evaluate the effect of clinic-based support by HIV-positive Peer Mentors, in addition to standard clinic care, on maternal and infant well-being among Women Living with HIV (WLH) from pregnancy through the infant's first year of life.\n\n\nMethods\nIn a cluster randomized controlled trial in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, eight clinics were randomized for pregnant WLH to receive either: a Standard Care condition (SC; 4 clinics; n?=?656 WLH); or an Enhanced Intervention (EI; 4 clinics; n?=?544 WLH).\n\n WLH in the EI were invited to attend four antenatal and four postnatal meetings led by HIV-positive Peer Mentors, in addition to SC.\n\n WLH were recruited during pregnancy, and at least two post-birth assessment interviews were completed by 57% of WLH at 1.5, 6 or 12 months.\n\n EI's effect was ascertained on 19 measures of maternal and infant well-being using random effects regressions to control for clinic clustering.\n\n A binomial test for correlated outcomes evaluated EI's overall efficacy.\n\n\nFindings\nWLH attended an average of 4.1 sessions (SD?=?2.0); 13% did not attend any sessions.\n\n Significant overall benefits were found in EI compared to SC using the binomial test.\n\n Secondarily, over time, WLH in the EI reported significantly fewer depressive symptoms and fewer underweight infants than WLH in the SC condition.\n\n EI WLH were significantly more likely to use one feeding method for six months and exclusively breastfeed their infants for at least 6 months.\n\n\nConclusions\nWLH benefit by support from HIV-positive Peer Mentors, even though EI participation was partial, with incomplete follow-up rates from 612 months.\n\n\nTrial The AIDS health workforce plan","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]}]},{"doi":"10.7448/IAS.18.1.19835","date":"2015-02-13","title":"Systematic review of stigma reducing interventions for African/Black diasporic women","abstract":"Introduction\nLiterature indicates that racism, sexism, homophobia and HIV-related stigma have adverse impacts on health, well-being, and quality of life among HIV-positive women of African descent (African/Black diaspora).\n\n However, limited evidence exists on the effectiveness of interventions aimed at reducing stigma tailored for these women.\n\n This study systematically reviewed randomized controlled trials (RCTs), non-randomized observational and quasi-experimental studies evaluating the effectiveness of interventions aimed at reducing stigma experienced by this population.\n\n\nMethods\nThe Cochrane methodology was used to develop a search strategy in consultation with a librarian scientist.\n\n Databases searched included the Cochrane Library, Ovid EMBASE, PsycInfo, and 10 others.\n\n Two reviewers independently assessed the studies for potential relevance and conducted the Cochrane grading of RCTs to assess risk of bias and the NewcastleOttawa scale to assess the quality of non-randomized studies.\n\n Eligible papers were selected if they employed an intervention design with African/Black diasporic women living with HIV as the target population and had a primary outcome of stigma reduction.\n\n\nResults\nOf the five studies that met all of the eligibility criteria, four demonstrated the effectiveness of interventions in reducing HIV-related stigma.\n\n Only two of the five studies were designed specifically for HIV-positive African/Black diasporic women.\n\n Limitations included the absence of interventions addressing other forms of stigma and discrimination (e.\n\ng.\n\n gender discrimination, racism, heterosexism).\n\n\nConclusions\nOur findings suggest that there are limited interventions designed to address multiple forms of stigma, including gender and racial discrimination, experienced by HIV-positive African/Black diasporic women.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4393416","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"International AIDS 2":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12978-015-0032-9","date":"2015-04-29","title":"Women living with HIV/AIDS (WLHA), battling stigma, discrimination and denial and the role of support groups as a coping strategy: a review of literature","abstract":"Background and objectives\nWomen living with HIV/AIDS, in particular, have been positioned as a latent source of infection, and have captivated culpability and blame leading to a highly stigmatised and discriminated life.\n\n Despite the situation, women and their particular concerns have largely been ignored in HIV/AIDS research literature.\n\n\nMethodology\nA systematic literature search was carried out on major data bases ASSIA, CINAHL, Science Direct, Web of Knowledge, Wiley Inter Science, AMED, Pub Med/Bio Med Central, MEDLINE and Cochrane Library.\n\n The articles included for review purpose were gauged against the pre-defined inclusion/exclusion criteria and quality assessment checklist resulting in a final 7 papers.\n\n\nFindings/results\nThe findings were compiled into five thematic areas: (1) Disclosure as a sensitive issue; (2) Stigma and Discrimination associated with HIV/AIDS and the multidimensional effects on womens health and wellbeing; (3) Internalised Stigma; (4) Women living with HIV/AIDS experiences of being rejected, shunned and treated differently by physicians, family and close friends; (5) Support Group as among the best available interventions for stigma and discrimination.\n\n\nConclusion\nSupport groups should be offered as a fundamental part of HIV/AIDS services and should be advocated as an effective and useful intervention.\n\n Further research is needed to examine the effect of support groups for women living with HIV/AIDS.\n\n A community based randomised controlled trial with support group as an intervention and a control group could provide further evidence of the value of support groups.\n\n\nElectronic supplementary material\nThe online version of this article (doi:10.1186/s12978-015-0032-9) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4467680","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed
