Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy for Social Anxiety Disorder in Romania: A Randomized Controlled Trial","abstract":"Background and Aims\nInternet-based cognitive-behavioral therapy (iCBT) for social anxiety disorder has been found effective, as attested by independently conducted randomized controlled trials in four languages.\n\n The study aim is to test the efficacy of an iCBT program in a culture where it was not tested before (i.\n\ne.\n\n Romania).\n\n\nMethods\nParticipants (n = 76) were recruited, screened and randomized to either a nine-week guided iCBT or a wait-list control group in April and May 2012. Self-report measures were collected before (April 2012) and after the intervention (July 2012), as well as six months later (January 2013).\n\n Although social anxiety was assessed with multiple measures, the Liebowitz Social Anxiety Scale - Self Report version (LSAS-SR) and Social Phobia Inventory (SPIN) were used as the primary outcome measures.\n\n\nResults\nA significant difference with a large between-group effect size in favor of iCBT was found (Cohen´s d = 1.19 for LSAS-SR and d = 1.27 for SPIN).\n\n Recovery rates show that 36.8% (n = 14) in the treatment group score below the SPIN clinical cut-off compared to only 2.6% (n = 1) in the wait-list control group.\n\n Post-intervention clinical interviews also revealed that 34.2% (n = 13) of the treatment group was completely recovered (full remission) while additionally 36.8% (n = 14) retained some social anxiety symptoms (partial remission).\n\n However, an important study limitation is that post-intervention interviewers were not blinded to the study conditions.\n\n The program also effectively reduced depression and dysfunctional thinking (between-group Cohen´s d = 0.84 for depression and d = 0.63 for dysfunctional thinking).\n\n Moreover, the iCBT intervention appears to have a long-term impact for participants functioning, as the treatment gains were maintained six months later.\n\n\nConclusions\nInternet-delivered interventions display a high potential to quickly and widely disseminate effective evidence-based programs around the world.\n\n This study provides support for guided iCBT as a promising treatment approach in Romania.\n\n\nTrial Registration\nClinicalTrials.\n\ngov NCT01557894\n\n","id":"PMC4418823","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of Science","authors":[{"firstname":"Bogdan Tudor","surname":"Tulbure","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Aurora","surname":"Szentagotai","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Oana","surname":"David","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Simona","surname":"?tefan","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Kristoffer N. Comparing Clinician vs. Technician Assistance","abstract":"Background\nInternet-based cognitive behavioural therapy (iCBT) for depression is effective when guided by a clinician, less so if unguided.\n\n Question: Would guidance from a technician be as effective as guidance from a clinician?\nMethod\nRandomized controlled non-inferiority trial comparing three groups: Clinician-assisted vs.\n\n technician-assisted vs.\n\n delayed treatment.\n\n Community-based volunteers applied to the VirtualClinic (www.\n\nvirtualclinic.\n\norg.\n\nau) research program, and 141 participants with major depressive disorder were randomized.\n\n Participants in the clinician- and technician-assisted groups received access to an iCBT program for depression comprising 6 online lessons, weekly homework assignments, and weekly supportive contact over a treatment period of 8 weeks.\n\n Participants in the clinician-assisted group also received access to a moderated online discussion forum.\n\n The main outcome measures were the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI-II) and the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 Item (PHQ-9).\n\n Completion rates were high, and at post-treatment, both treatment groups reduced scores on the BDI-II (p&lt;0.001) and PHQ-9 (p&lt;0.001) compared to the delayed treatment group but did not differ from each other.\n\n Within group effect sizes on the BDI-II were 1.27 and 1.20 for the clinician- and technician-assisted groups respectively, and on the PHQ-9, were 1.54 and 1.60 respectively.\n\n At 4-month follow-up participants in the technician group had made further improvements and had significantly lower scores on the PHQ-9 than those in the clinician group.\n\n A total of approximately 60 minutes of clinician or technician time was required per participant during the 8-week treatment program.\n\n\nConclusions\nBoth clinician- and technician-assisted treatment resulted in large effect sizes and clinically significant improvements comparable to those associated with face-to-face treatment, while a delayed treatment control group did not improve.\n\n These results provide support for large scale trials to determine the clinical effectiveness and acceptability of technician-assisted iCBT programs for depression.\n\n This form of treatment has potential to increase the capacity of existing mental health services.\n\n\nTrial found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1016/S0140-6736(11)61093-3","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Human resources for mental health care: current situation and strategies for action","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1016/S2215-0366(14)00023-6","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Mental health-related stigma in health care and mental health-care settings","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1472-6963-10-286","date":"2010-10-13","title":"A realist synthesis of randomised control trials involving use of community health workers for delivering child health interventions in low and middle income countries","abstract":"Background\nA key constraint to saturating coverage of interventions for reducing the burden of childhood illnesses in Low and Middle Income Countries (LMIC) is the lack of human resources.\n\n Community health workers (CHW) are potentially important actors in bridging this gap.\n\n Evidence exists on effectiveness of CHW in management of some childhood illnesses (IMCI).\n\n However, we need to know how and when this comes to be.\n\n We examine evidence from randomized control trials (RCT) on CHW interventions in IMCI in LMIC from a realist perspective with the aim to see if they can yield insight into the working of the interventions, when examined from a different perspective.\n\n\nMethods\nThe realist approach involves educing the mechanisms through which an intervention produced an outcome in a particular context.\n\n 'Mechanisms' are reactions, triggered by the interaction of the intervention and a certain context, which lead to change.\n\n These are often only implicit and are actually hypothesized by the reviewer.\n\n This review is limited to unravelling these from the RCTs; it is thus a hypothesis generating exercise.\n\n\nResults\nInterventions to improve CHW performance included 'Skills based training of CHW', 'Supervision and referral support from public health services', 'Positioning of CHW in the community'.\n\n When interventions were applied in context of CHW programs embedded in local health services, with beneficiaries who valued services and had unmet needs, the interventions worked if following mechanisms were triggered: anticipation of being valued by the community; perception of improvement in social status; sense of relatedness with beneficiaries and public services; increase in self esteem; sense of self efficacy and enactive mastery of tasks; sense of credibility, legitimacy and assurance that there was a system for back-up support.\n\n Studies also showed that if context differed, even with similar interventions, negative mechanisms could be triggered, compromising CHW performance.\n\n\nConclusion\nThe aim of this review was to explore if RCTs could yield insight into the working of the interventions, when examined from a different, a realist perspective.\n\n We found that RCTs did yield some insight, but the hypotheses generated were very general and not well refined.\n\n These hypotheses need to be tested and refined in further studies.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2964693","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed Central","authors":[{"firstname":"Sumit S","surname":"Kane","email":"s.kane@kit.nl","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Barend","surname":"Gerretsen","email":"b.gerretsen@kit.nl","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Robert","surname":"Scherpbier","email":"scherpbierr@who.int","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Mario","surname":"Dal Poz","email":"dalpozm@who.int","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Marjolein","surname":"Dieleman","email":"m.dieleman@kit.nl","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1136/qshc.7.3.149","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Enabling into practice: how middle and low income countries &quot;get it together&quot;","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1748-5908-8-75","date":"2013-06-24","title":"Improving implementation of evidence-based practice in mental health service delivery: protocol for a cluster randomised quasi-experimental investigation of staff-focused values interventions","abstract":"Background\nThere is growing acceptance that optimal service provision for individuals with severe and recurrent mental illness requires a complementary focus on medical recovery (i.\n\ne.\n\n, symptom management and general functioning) and personal recovery (i.\n\ne.\n\n, having a life worth living).\n\n Despite significant research attention and policy-level support, the translation of this vision of healthcare into changed workplace practice continues to elude.\n\n Over the past decade, evidence-based training interventions that seek to enhance the knowledge, attitudes, and skills of staff working in the mental health field have been implemented as a primary redress strategy.\n\n However, a large body of multi-disciplinary research indicates disappointing rates of training transfer.\n\n There is an absence of empirical research that investigates the importance of worker-motivation in the uptake of desired workplace change initiatives.\n\n Autonomy is acknowledged as important to human effectiveness and as a correlate of workplace variables like productivity, and wellbeing.\n\n To our knowledge, there have been no studies that investigate purposeful and structured use of values-based interventions to facilitate increased autonomy as a means of promoting enhanced implementation of workplace change.\n\n\nMethods\nThis study involves 200 mental health workers across 22 worksites within five community-managed organisations in three Australian states.\n\n It involves cluster-randomisation of participants within organisation, by work site, to the experimental (values) condition, or the control (implementation).\n\n Both conditions receive two days of training focusing on an evidence-based framework of mental health service delivery.\n\n The experimental group receives a third day of values-focused intervention and 12 months of values-focused coaching.\n\n Well-validated self-report measures are used to explore variables related to values concordance, autonomy, and self-reported implementation success.\n\n Audits of work files and staff work samples are reviewed for each condition to determine the impact of implementation.\n\n Self-determination theory and theories of organisational change are used to interpret the data.\n\n\nDiscussion\nThe research adds to the current knowledge base related to worker motivation and uptake of workplace practice.\n\n It describes a structured protocol that aims to enhance worker autonomy for imposed workplace practices.\n\n The research will inform how best to measure and conceptualise transfer.\n\n These findings will apply particularly to contexts where individuals are not volunteers in requisite change processes.\n\n\nTrial registration\nACTRN: ACTRN12613000353796.\n","id":"PMC3722111","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed G","surname":"Oades","email":"loades@uow.edu.au","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Frank P","surname":"Deane","email":"fdeane@uow.edu.au","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Trevor P","surname":"Crowe","email":"tcrowe@uow.edu.au","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Joseph","surname":"Ciarrochi","email":"j.ciarrochi@uws.edu.au","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Retta","surname":"Andresen","email":"retta@uow.edu.au","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1186/1748-5908-6-1","date":"2011-01-05","title":"Individual determinants of research utilization by nurses: a systematic review update","abstract":"Background\nInterventions that have a better than random chance of increasing nurses' use of research are important to the delivery of quality patient care.\n\n However, few reports exist of successful research utilization in nursing interventions.\n\n Systematic identification and evaluation of individual characteristics associated with and predicting research utilization may inform the development of research utilization interventions.\n\n\nObjective\nTo update the evidence published in a previous systematic review on individual characteristics influencing research utilization by nurses.\n\n\nMethods\nAs part of a larger systematic review on research utilization instruments, 12 online bibliographic databases were searched.\n\n Hand searching of specialized journals and an ancestry search was also conducted.\n\n Randomized controlled trials, clinical trials, and observational study designs examining the association between individual characteristics and nurses' use of research were eligible for inclusion.\n\n Studies were limited to those published in the English, Danish, Swedish, and Norwegian languages.\n\n A vote counting approach to data synthesis was taken.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 42,770 titles were identified, of which 501 were retrieved.\n\n Of these 501 articles, 45 satisfied our inclusion criteria.\n\n Articles assessed research utilization in general (n = 39) or kinds of research utilization (n = 6) using self-report survey measures.\n\n Individual nurse characteristics were classified according to six categories: beliefs and attitudes, involvement in research activities, information seeking, education, professional characteristics, and socio-demographic/socio-economic characteristics.\n\n A seventh category, critical thinking, emerged in studies examining kinds of research utilization.\n\n Positive relationships, at statistically significant levels, for general research utilization were found in four categories: beliefs and attitudes, information seeking, education, and professional characteristics.\n\n The only characteristic assessed in a sufficient number of studies and with consistent findings for the kinds of research utilization was attitude towards research; this characteristic had a positive association with instrumental and overall research utilization.\n\n\nConclusions\nThis review reinforced conclusions in the previous review with respect to positive relationships between general research utilization and: beliefs and attitudes, and current role.\n\n Furthermore, attending conferences/in-services, having a graduate degree in nursing, working in a specialty area, and job satisfaction were also identified as individual characteristics important to research utilization.\n\n While these findings hold promise as potential targets of future research utilization interventions, there were methodological problems inherent in many of the studies that necessitate their findings be replicated in further research using more robust study designs and multivariate assessment methods.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3024963","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed Central","authors":[{"firstname":"Janet E","surname":"Squires","email":"jasquires@ohri.ca","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Carole A","surname":"Estabrooks","email":"carole.estabrooks@ualberta.ca","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Petter","surname":"Gustavsson","email":"petter.gustavsson@ki.se","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Lars","surname":"Wallin","email":"lars.wallin@karolinska.se","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pmed.0020246","date":"2005-06-13","title":"Discriminatory Attitudes and Practices by Health Workers toward Patients with HIV/AIDS in Nigeria","abstract":"Background\nNigeria has an estimated 3.6 million people with HIV/AIDS and is home to one out of every 11 people with HIV/AIDS worldwide.\n\n This study is the first population-based assessment of discrimination against people living with HIV/AIDS in the health sector of a country.\n\n The purpose of this study was to characterize the nature and extent of discriminatory practices and attitudes in the health sector and indicate possible contributing factors and intervention strategies.\n\n The study involved a cross-sectional survey of 1,021 Nigerian health-care professionals (including 324 physicians, 541 nurses, and 133 midwives identified by profession) in 111 health-care facilities in four Nigerian states.\n\n\nMethods and Findings\nFifty-four percent of the health-care professionals (550/1,021) were sampled from public tertiary care facilities.\n\n Nine percent of professionals reported refusing to care for an HIV/AIDS patient, and 9% indicated that they had refused an HIV/AIDS patient admission to a hospital.\n\n Fifty-nine percent agreed that people with HIV/AIDS should be on a separate ward, and 40% believed a person's HIV status could be determined by his or her appearance.\n\n Ninety-one percent agreed that staff and health-care professionals should be informed when a patient is HIV-positive so they can protect themselves.\n\n Forty percent believed that health-care professionals with HIV/AIDS should not be allowed to work in any area of health-care that requires patient contact.\n\n Twenty percent agreed that many with HIV/AIDS behaved immorally and deserve the disease.\n\n Basic materials needed for treatment and prevention of HIV were not adequately available.\n\n Twelve percent agreed that treatment of opportunistic infections in HIV/AIDS patients wastes resources, and 8% indicated that treating someone with HIV/AIDS is a waste of precious resources.\n\n Providers who reported working in facilities that did not always practice universal precautions were more likely to favor restrictive policies toward people with HIV/AIDS.\n\n Providers who reported less adequate training in HIV treatment and ethics were also more likely to report negative attitudes toward patients with HIV/AIDS.\n\n There was no consistent pattern of differences in negative attitudes and practices across the different health specialties surveyed.\n\n\nConclusion\nWhile most health-care professionals surveyed reported being in compliance with their ethical obligations despite the lack of resources, discriminatory behavior and attitudes toward patients with HIV/AIDS exist among a significant proportion of health-care professionals in the surveyed states.\n\n Inadequate education about HIV/AIDS and a lack of protective and treatment materials appear to contribute to these practices and attitudes.\n\n\n","id":"PMC1176239","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of which mental health services are provided in the country and the limited budget allocations, with mental health services receiving 0.4% of the total health budget.\n\n Most of the mental health services provided are curative in nature and based in tertiary health institutions.\n\n At primary health care level, there is either absence of, or fragmented health services.\n\n\nAims\nThe aim of this paper was to explore health providers' views about mental health integration into primary health care.\n\n\nMethods\nA mixed methods, structured survey was conducted of 111 health service care from care providers, as a way of facilitating early detection and intervention for mental health problems.\n\n Participants believed that this would contribute to the reduction of stigma and the promotion of human rights for people with mental health problems.\n\n However, health providers felt they require basic training in order to enhance their knowledge and skills in providing health care to people with mental health problems.\n\n\nRecommendations\nIt is recommended that health care providers should be provided with basic training in mental health in order to enhance their knowledge and skills to enable them provide mental health care to patients seeking help at primary health care level.\n\n\nConclusion\nIntegrating mental health services into primary health care is critical to attitudes and behaviour.\n\n\nResults\nThe total scores of RIBS, MAKS and MICA were (11.97?±?3.41), (16.80?±?5.39) and (51.69?±?6.94) respectively.\n\n Female staff members were more willing to contact people with mental illness than males (t(212)?=??2.85,P?=?0.005) and had more knowledge about mental illness (t(212)?=??2.28,P?=?0.024).\n\n The Chinese version of RIBS had good internal consistency (alpha?=?0.82), test-retest reliability (r?=?0.68,P?&lt;?0.001) and adequate convergent validity, as indicated by a significant negative correlation with the Chinese version of MICA(r?=??0.43, P?&lt;?0.001).\n\n\nConclusions\nOur results show relatively high levels of stigma toward people with mental illness among community mental health staff in Guangzhou, China.\n\n There are slightly gender differences in discriminatory behaviours and stigma related knowledge of mental illness among community mental health staff, with female staff in general less stigmatising.\n\n Accordingly, anti-stigma programmes should be established among healthcare staff.\n\n In addition, the Chinese version of RIBS is a reliable, valid and acceptable measure which can be used to assess towards a patient with mental illness than towards a patients with a general health problem - diabetes.\n\n\nMethods\nGeneral hospital health professionals in Malaysia were randomly allocated one of two vignettes, one describing a patient with mental illness and the other a patient with diabetes, and invited to complete a questionnaire examining attitudes and health care practices in relation to the case.\n\n The questionnaires completed by respondents included questions on demographics, training in mental health, exposure in clinical practice to people with mental illness, attitudes and expected health care behaviour towards the patient in the vignette, and a general questionnaire exploring negative attitudes towards people with mental illness.\n\n Questionnaires with complete responses were received from 654 study participants.\n\n\nResults\nStigmatising attitudes towards persons with mental illness were common.\n\n Those responding to the mental illness vignette (N = 356) gave significantly lower ratings on care and support and higher ratings on avoidance and negative stereotype expectations compared with those responding the diabetes vignette (N = 298).\n\n\nConclusions\nResults support the view that, in the Malaysian setting, patients with mental illness may receive differential care from general hospital staff and that general stigmatising healthcare provision for people with severe mental illness","abstract":"There are many factors that contribute to the poor physical health of people with severe mental illness (SMI), including lifestyle factors and medication side effects.\n However, there is increasing evidence that disparities in healthcare provision contribute to poor physical health outcomes.\n These inequalities have been attributed to a combination of factors including systemic issues, such as the separation of mental health services from other medical services, healthcare provider issues including the pervasive stigma associated with mental illness, and consequences of mental illness and side effects of its treatment.\n A number of solutions have been proposed.\n To tackle systemic barriers to healthcare provision integrated care models could be employed including co-location of physical and mental health services or the use of case managers or other staff to undertake a co-ordination or liaison role between services.\n The health care sector could be targeted for programmes aimed at reducing the stigma of mental illness.\n The cognitive deficits and other consequences of SMI could be addressed through the provision of healthcare skills training to people with SMI or by the use of peer supporters.\n Population health and health promotion approaches could be developed and targeted at this population, by integrating health promotion activities across domains of interest.\n To date there have only been small-scale trials to evaluate these ideas suggesting that a range of models may have benefit.\n More work is needed to build the evidence base in this area.\n","id":"PMC2951586","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"SAGE contact interventions and their effect on mental health related stigma and intended discrimination","abstract":"Background\nStigma and discrimination associated with mental health problems is an important public health issue, and interventions aimed at reducing exposure to stigma and discrimination can improve the lives of people with mental health problems.\n\n Social contact has long been considered to be one of the most effective strategies for improving inter-group relations.\n\n For this study, we assess the impact of a population level social contact intervention among people with and without mental health problems.\n\n\nMethods\nThis study investigated the impact of social contact and whether presence of specific facilitating factors (equal status, common goals, cooperation and friendship potential): (1) improves intended stigmatising behaviour; (2) increases future willingness to disclose a mental health problem; and (3) promotes behaviours associated with anti-stigma campaign engagement.\n\n Two mass participation social contact programmes within Englands Time to Change campaign were evaluated via a 2-part questionnaire.\n\n 403 participants completed initial questionnaires (70% paper, 30% online) and 83 completed follow-up questionnaires online 46 weeks later.\n\n\nResults\nThis study investigated the impact of social contact and whether presence of specific facilitating factors (equal status, common goals, cooperation and friendship potential): (1) improves intended stigmatising behaviour; (2) increases future willingness to disclose a mental health problem; and (3) promotes behaviours associated with anti-stigma campaign engagement.\n\n Two mass participation social contact programmes within Englands Time to Change campaign were evaluated via a 2-part questionnaire.\n\n 403 participants completed initial questionnaires (70% paper, 30% online) and 83 completed follow-up questionnaires online 46 weeks later.\n\n Campaign events facilitated meaningful intergroup social contact between individuals with and without mental health problems.\n\n Presence of facilitating conditions predicted improved stigma-related behavioural intentions and subsequent campaign engagement 46 weeks following social contact.\n\n Contact, however, was not predictive of future willingness to disclose mental health problems.\n\n\nConclusions\nFindings emphasise the importance of facilitating conditions to promote positive social contact between individuals and also suggest that social contact interventions can work on a mass level.\n\n Future research should investigate this type of large scale intervention among broader and more representative populations.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3461459","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed example of the Scottish Births Survey","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1471-2288-10-1","date":"2010-01-06","title":"A tutorial on pilot studies: the what, why and how","abstract":"Pilot studies for phase III trials - which are comparative randomized trials designed to provide preliminary evidence on the clinical efficacy of a drug or intervention - are routinely performed in many clinical areas.\n Also commonly know as 'feasibility' or 'vanguard' studies, they are designed to assess the safety of treatment or interventions; to assess recruitment potential; to assess the feasibility of international collaboration or coordination for multicentre trials; to increase clinical experience with the study medication or intervention for the phase III trials.\n They are the best way to assess feasibility of a large, expensive full-scale study, and in fact are an almost essential pre-requisite.\n Conducting a pilot prior to the main study can enhance the likelihood of success of the main study and potentially help to avoid doomed main studies.\n The objective of this paper is to provide a detailed examination of the key aspects of pilot studies for phase III trials including: 1) the general reasons for conducting a pilot study; 2) the relationships between pilot studies, proof-of-concept studies, and adaptive designs; 3) the challenges of and misconceptions about pilot studies; 4) the criteria for evaluating the success of a pilot study; 5) frequently asked questions about pilot studies; 7) some ethical aspects related to pilot studies; and 8) some suggestions on how to report the results of pilot investigations using the CONSORT format.\n","id":"PMC2824145","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed We used the World Health Organizations Disability Assessment Schedule-II (WHO-DAS II) with additional local items to assess disability symptoms and a separate checklist to identify their perceived needs.\n\n Depression and anxiety symptoms were measured using the Hopkins Symptom Check List (HSCL-25), while the Posttraumatic Stress Disorder Checklist Civilian Version (PCL-C) was used to assess Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) symptoms.\n\n\nResults\nDifferent perceived needs such as financial help (70%), housing (40%), food and education for their children (20%) were expressed by the IDPs.\n\n Self-reported health status was strongly associated with distress and disability scores.\n\n Factors independently associated with disability were higher age, self-reported health, depression, anxiety but not PTSD.\n\n There was good correlation between WHO-DAS II and the locally identified items of disability measurement.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe reporting of findings only about psychiatric symptoms is insufficient in studying the mental health of displaced and potentially traumatized populations living in low-income countries.\n\n Assessments of perceived needs and factors associated with disability give a more comprehensive understanding of the underlying needs among crisis populations, and this can inform intervention programs.\n\n Depression and anxiety should be treated effectively to avoid disability.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3304067","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Springer-Verlag","authors":[{"firstname":"Suraj Bahadur","surname":"Thapa","email":"thapasuraj@hotmail.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Edvard","surname":"Hauff","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Suvedi BK, Pradhan A, Barnett S, Puri M, Chitrakar SR, Poudel P, Sharma S, Hulton L: Nepal maternal mortality and morbidity study 2008/2009: summary of preliminary findings. found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/s13031-014-0030-5","date":"2014-12-26","title":"Mental health care in Nepal: current situation and challenges for development of a district mental health care plan","abstract":"Background\nGlobally mental health problems are a serious public health concern.\n\n Currently four out of five people with severe mental illness in Low and Middle Income Countries (LMIC) receive no effective treatment.\n\n There is an urgent need to address this enormous treatment gap.\n\n Changing the focus of specialist mental health workers (psychiatrists and psychologists) from only service delivery to also designing and managing mental health services; building clinical capacity of the primary health care (PHC) workers, and providing supervision and quality assurance of mental health services may help in scaling up mental health services in LMICs.\n\n Little is known however, about the mental health policy and services context for these strategies in fragile-state settings, such as Nepal.\n\n\nMethod\nA standard situation analysis tool was developed by the PRogramme for Improving Mental health carE (PRIME) consortium to systematically analyze and describe the current gaps in mental health care in Nepal, in order to inform the development of a district level mental health care plan (MHCP).\n\n It comprised six sections; general information (e.\n\ng.\n\n population, socio-economic conditions); mental health policies and plans; mental health treatment coverage; district health services; and community services.\n\n Data was obtained from secondary sources, including scientific publications, reports, project documents and hospital records.\n\n\nResults\nMental health policy exists in Nepal, having been adopted in 1997, but implementation of the policy framework has yet to begin.\n\n In common with other LMICs, the budget allocated for mental health is minimal.\n\n Mental health services are concentrated in the big cities, with 0.22 psychiatrists and 0.06 psychologists per 100,000 population.\n\n The key challenges experienced in developing a district level MHCP included, overburdened health workers, lack of psychotropic medicines in the PHC, lack of mental health supervision in the existing system, and lack of a coordinating body in the Ministry of Health and Population (MoHP).\n\n Strategies to overcome these challenges included involvement of MoHP in the process, especially by providing psychotropic medicines and appointing a senior level officer to facilitate project activities, and collaboration with National Health Training Centers (NHTC) in training programs.\n\n\nConclusions\nThis study describes many challenges facing mental health care in Nepal.\n\n Most of these challenges are not new, yet this study contributes to our understanding of these difficulties by outlining the national and district level factors that have a direct influence on the development of a district level mental health care plan.\n\n\nElectronic supplementary material\nThe online version of this article (doi:10.1186/s13031-014-0030-5) contains supplementary and Opportunities for Implementing Integrated Mental Health Care: A District Level Situation Analysis from Five Low- and Middle-Income Countries","abstract":"Background\nLittle is known about how to tailor implementation of mental health services in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) to the diverse settings encountered within and between countries.\n\n In this paper we compare the baseline context, challenges and opportunities in districts in five LMICs (Ethiopia, India, Nepal, South Africa and Uganda) participating in the PRogramme for Improving Mental health carE (PRIME).\n\n The purpose was to inform development and implementation of a comprehensive district plan to integrate mental health into primary care.\n\n\nMethods\nA situation analysis tool was developed for the study, drawing on existing tools and expert consensus.\n\n Cross-sectional information obtained was largely in the public domain in all five districts.\n\n\nResults\nThe PRIME study districts face substantial contextual and health system challenges many of which are common across sites.\n\n Reliable information on existing treatment coverage for mental disorders was unavailable.\n\n Particularly in the low-income countries, many health service organisational requirements for mental health care were absent, including specialist mental health professionals to support the service and reliable supplies of medication.\n\n Across all sites, community mental health literacy was low and there were no models of multi-sectoral working or collaborations with traditional or religious healers.\n\n Nonetheless health system opportunities were apparent.\n\n In each district there was potential to apply existing models of care for tuberculosis and HIV or non-communicable disorders, which have established mechanisms for detection of drop-out from care, outreach and adherence support.\n\n The extensive networks of community-based health workers and volunteers in most districts provide further opportunities to expand mental health care.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe low level of baseline health system preparedness across sites underlines that interventions at the levels of health care organisation, health facility and community will all be essential for sustainable delivery of quality mental health care integrated into primary care.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3928234","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of Silva","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Martin","surname":"Prince","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ali","surname":"Montazeri","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Ali","surname":"Montazeri","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.socscimed.2014.07.057","date":"2014-07-27","title":"Acceptability and feasibility of using non-specialist health workers to deliver mental health care: Stakeholder perceptions from the PRIME district sites in Ethiopia, India, Nepal, South Africa, and Uganda","abstract":"Three-quarters of the global mental health burden exists in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), yet the lack of mental health services in resource-poor settings is striking.\n Task-sharing (also, task-shifting), where mental health care is provided by non-specialists, has been proposed to improve access to mental health care in LMICs.\n This multi-site qualitative study investigates the acceptability and feasibility of task-sharing mental health care in LMICs by examining perceptions of primary care service providers (physicians, nurses, and community health workers), community members, and service users in one district in each of the five countries participating in the PRogramme for Improving Mental health carE (PRIME): Ethiopia, India, Nepal, South Africa, and Uganda.\n Thirty-six focus group discussions and 164 in-depth interviews were conducted at the pre-implementation stage between February and October 2012 with the objective of developing district level plans to integrate mental health care into primary care.\n Perceptions of the acceptability and feasibility of task-sharing were evaluated first at the district level in each country through open-coding and then at the cross-country level through a secondary analysis of emergent themes.\n We found that task-sharing mental health services is perceived to be acceptable and feasible in these LMICs as long as key conditions are met: 1) increased numbers of human resources and better access to medications; 2) ongoing structured supportive supervision at the community and primary care-levels; and 3) adequate training and compensation for health workers involved in task-sharing.\n Taking into account the socio-cultural context is fundamental for identifying local personnel who can assist in detection of mental illness and facilitate treatment and care as well as training, supervision, and service delivery.\n By recognizing the systemic challenges and sociocultural nuances that may influence task-sharing mental health care, locally-situated interventions could be more easily planned to provide appropriate and acceptable mental health care in LMICs.\n","id":"PMC4167946","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Pergamon","authors":[{"firstname":"Emily","surname":"Mendenhall","email":"em1061@georgetown.edu","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Mary Br J Psychiatry. 2016;208(s56):s47-54.","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/s13033-015-0020-z","date":"2015-06-26","title":"Stakeholder analysis of the Programme for Improving Mental health carE (PRIME): baseline findings","abstract":"Background\nThe knowledge generated from evidence-based interventions in mental health systems research is seldom translated into policy and practice in low and middle-income countries (LMIC).\n\n Stakeholder analysis is a potentially useful tool in health policy and systems research to improve understanding of policy stakeholders and increase the likelihood of knowledge\ntranslation into policy and practice.\n\n The aim of this study was to conduct stakeholder analyses in the five countries participating in the Programme for Improving Mental health carE (PRIME); evaluate a template used for cross-country comparison of stakeholder analyses; and assess the utility of stakeholder analysis for future use in mental health policy and systems research in LMIC.\n\n\nMethods\nUsing an adapted stakeholder analysis instrument, PRIME country teams in Ethiopia, India, Nepal, South Africa and Uganda identified and characterised stakeholders in relation to the proposed action: scaling-up mental health services.\n\n Qualitative content analysis was conducted for stakeholder groups across countries, and a force field analysis was applied to the data.\n\n\nResults\nStakeholder analysis of PRIME has identified policy makers (WHO, Ministries of Health, non-health sector Ministries and Parliament), donors (DFID UK, DFID country offices and other donor agencies), mental health specialists, the media (national and district) and universities as the most powerful, and most supportive actors for scaling up mental health care in the respective PRIME countries.\n\n Force field analysis provided a means of evaluating cross-country stakeholder power and positions, particularly for prioritising potential stakeholder engagement in the programme.\n\n\nConclusion\nStakeholder analysis has been helpful as a research uptake management tool to identify targeted and acceptable strategies for stimulating the demand for research amongst knowledge users, including policymakers and practitioners.\n\n Implementing these strategies amongst stakeholders at a country level will hopefully reduce the knowledge gap between research and policy, and improve health system outcomes for the programme.\n\n\nElectronic supplementary material\nThe online version of this article (doi:10.1186/s13033-015-0020-z) contains supplementary found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Training psychosocial counselling in Nepal: content review of a specialised training programme","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1745-6215-15-101","date":"2014-03-19","title":"The effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of lay counsellor-delivered psychological treatments for harmful and dependent drinking and moderate to severe depression in primary care in India: PREMIUM study protocol for randomized controlled trials","abstract":"Background\nThe leading mental health causes of the global burden of disease are depression in women and alcohol use disorders in men.\n\n A major hurdle to the implementation of evidence-based psychological treatments in primary care in developing countries is the non-availability of skilled human resources.\n\n The aim of these trials is to evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of two psychological treatments developed for the treatment of depression and alcohol use disorders in primary care in India.\n\n\nMethods/design\nThis study protocol is for parallel group, randomized controlled trials (Healthy Activity Program for moderate to severe depression, Counselling for Alcohol Problems for harmful and dependent drinking) in eight primary health centres in Goa, India.\n\n Adult primary care attendees will be screened with the Patient Health Questionnaire for depression and, in men only, the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test for drinking problems.\n\n Screen-positive attendees will be invited to participate; men who screen positive for both disorders will be invited to participate in the Counselling for Alcohol Problems trial.\n\n Those who consent will be allocated in a 1:1 ratio to receive either the respective psychological treatment plus enhanced usual care or enhanced usual care only using a computer generated allocation sequence, stratified by primary health centre and, for depression, by sex.\n\n The enhanced usual care comprises providing primary health centre doctors with contextualized World Health Organization guidelines and screening results.\n\n Psychological treatments will be delivered by lay counsellors, over a maximum period of three months.\n\n Primary outcomes are severity of disorder and remission rates at three months post-enrolment and, for the Counselling for Alcohol Problems trial, drinking and the impact of drinking on daily lives.\n\n Secondary outcomes include severity of disorder and remission rates at 12?months, disability scores, suicidal behaviour and economic impact, and cost-effectiveness at three and 12?months.\n\n 500 participants with depression and 400 participants with harmful drinking will be recruited.\n\n Primary analyses will be intention-to-treat.\n\n\nDiscussion\nThese trials may offer a new approach for the treatment of moderate-severe depression and drinking problems in primary care that is potentially scalable as it relies on delivery by a single pool of lay counsellors.\n\n\nTrial registration\nBoth trials are registered with the International Society for the Registration of Clinical Trials (Healthy Activity Programme registration number ISRCTN95149997; Counselling for Alcohol Problems registration number ISRCTN76465238).\n\n\n","id":"PMC4230277","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed D","surname":"Hollon","email":"Steven.d.hollon@vanderbilt.edu","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Michael","surname":"King","email":"Michael.king@ucl.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jim","surname":"McCambridge","email":"Jim.McCambridge@lshtm.ac.uk","contributions":"3"},{"firstname":"David","surname":"McDaid","email":"d.mcdaid@lse.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Pratima","surname":"Murthy","email":"pratimamurthy@gmail.com","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Richard","surname":"Velleman","email":"r.d.b.velleman@bath.ac.uk","contributions":"3"},{"firstname":"Christopher G","surname":"Fairburn","email":"credo@medsci.ox.ac.uk","contributions":"3"},{"firstname":"Betty","surname":"Kirkwood","email":"betty.kirkwood@lshtm.ac.uk","contributions":"2"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/S0140-6736(16)31589-6","date":"1970-01-01","title":"The Healthy Activity Program (HAP), a lay counsellor-delivered brief psychological treatment for severe depression, in primary care in India: a randomised controlled trial","abstract":"Background\nAlthough structured psychological treatments are recommended as first-line interventions for depression, only a small fraction of people globally receive these treatments because of poor access in routine primary care.\n\n We assessed the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a brief psychological treatment (Healthy Activity Program [HAP]) for delivery by lay counsellors to patients with moderately severe to severe depression in primary health-care settings.\n\n\nMethods\nIn this randomised controlled trial, we recruited participants aged 1865 years scoring more than 14 on the Patient Health Questionnaire 9 (PHQ-9) indicating moderately severe to severe depression from ten primary health centres in Goa, India.\n\n Pregnant women or patients who needed urgent medical attention or were unable to communicate clearly were not eligible.\n\n Participants were randomly allocated (1:1) to enhanced usual care (EUC) alone or EUC combined with HAP in randomly sized blocks (block size four to six [two to four for men]), stratified by primary health centre and sex, and allocation was concealed with use of sequential numbered opaque envelopes.\n\n Physicians providing EUC were masked.\n\n Primary outcomes were depression symptom severity on the Beck Depression Inventory version II and remission from depression (PHQ-9 score of &lt;10) at 3 months in the intention-to-treat population, assessed by masked field researchers.\n\n Secondary outcomes were disability, days unable to work, behavioural activation, suicidal thoughts or attempts, intimate partner violence, and resource use and costs of illness.\n\n We assessed serious adverse events in the per-protocol population.\n\n This trial is registered with the ISRCTN registry, number ISRCTN95149997.\nFindings\nBetween Oct 28, 2013, and July 29, 2015, we enrolled and randomly allocated 495 participants (247 [50%] to the EUC plus HAP group [two of whom were subsequently excluded because of protocol violations] and 248 [50%] to the EUC alone group), of whom 466 (95%) completed the 3 month primary outcome assessment (230 [49%] in the EUC plus HAP group and 236 [51%] in the EUC alone group).\n\n Participants in the EUC plus HAP group had significantly lower symptom severity (Beck Depression Inventory version II in EUC plus HAP group 19·99 [SD 15·70] vs 27·52 [13·26] in EUC alone group; adjusted mean difference ?7·57 [95% CI ?10·27 to ?4·86]; p&lt;0·0001) and higher remission (147 [64%] of 230 had a PHQ-9 score of &lt;10 in the HAP plus EUC group vs 91 [39%] of 236 in the EUC alone group; adjusted prevalence ratio 1·61 [1·341·93]) than did those in the EUC alone group.\n\n EUC plus HAP showed better results than did EUC alone for the secondary outcomes of disability (adjusted mean difference ?2·73 [4·39 to ?1·06]; p=0·001), days out of work (?2·29 [3·84 to ?0·73]; p=0·004), intimate partner physical violence in women (0·53 [0·290·96]; p=0·04), behavioural activation (2·17 [1·343·00]; p&lt;0·0001), and suicidal thoughts or attempts (0·61 [0·450·83]; p=0·001).\n\n The incremental cost per quality-adjusted life-year gained was $9333 (95% CI 386228?169; 2015 international dollars), with an 87% chance of being cost-effective in the study setting.\n\n Serious adverse events were infrequent and similar between groups (nine [4%] in the EUC plus HAP group vs ten [4%] in the EUC alone group; p=1·00).\n\n\nInterpretation\nHAP delivered by lay counsellors plus EUC was better than EUC alone was for patients with moderately severe to severe depression in routine primary care in Goa, India.\n\n HAP was readily accepted by this previously untreated population and was cost-effective in this setting.\n\n HAP could be a key strategy to reduce the treatment gap for depressive disorders, the leading mental health disorder worldwide.\n\n\nFunding\nWellcome Trust.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5236064","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Elsevier","authors":[{"firstname":"Vikram","surname":"Patel","email":"vikram.patel@lshtm.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Benedict","surname":"Weobong","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Helen D","surname":"Hollon","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Michael","surname":"King","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Lakshmi","surname":"Vijayakumar","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"A-La","surname":"Park","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"David","surname":"McDaid","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Terry","surname":"Wilson","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Richard","surname":"Velleman","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Betty R","surname":"Kirkwood","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Christopher G","surname":"Fairburn","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/S0140-6736(16)31590-2","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Counselling for Alcohol Problems (CAP), a lay counsellor-delivered brief psychological treatment for harmful drinking in men, in primary care in India: a randomised controlled trial","abstract":"Background\nAlthough structured psychological treatments are recommended as first-line interventions for harmful drinking, only a small fraction of people globally receive these treatments because of poor access in routine primary care.\n\n We assessed the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of Counselling for Alcohol Problems (CAP), a brief psychological treatment delivered by lay counsellors to patients with harmful drinking attending routine primary health-care settings.\n\n\nMethods\nIn this randomised controlled trial, we recruited male harmful drinkers defined by an Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT) score of 1219 who were aged 1865 years from ten primary health centres in Goa, India.\n\n We excluded patients who needed emergency medical treatment or inpatient admission, who were unable to communicate clearly, and who were intoxicated at the time of screening.\n\n Participants were randomly allocated (1:1) by trained health assistants based at the primary health centres to enhanced usual care (EUC) alone or EUC combined with CAP, in randomly sized blocks of four to six, stratified by primary health centre, and allocation was concealed with use of sequential numbered opaque envelopes.\n\n Physicians providing EUC and those assessing outcomes were masked.\n\n Primary outcomes were remission (AUDIT score of &lt;8) and mean daily alcohol consumed in the past 14 days, at 3 months.\n\n Secondary outcomes were the effect of drinking, disability score, days unable to work, suicide attempts, intimate partner violence, and resource use and costs of illness.\n\n Analyses were on an intention-to-treat basis.\n\n We used logistic regression analysis for remission and zero-inflated negative binomial regression analysis for alcohol consumption.\n\n We assessed serious adverse events in the per-protocol population.\n\n This trial is registered with the ISCRTN registry, number ISRCTN76465238.\nFindings\nBetween Oct 28, 2013, and July 29, 2015, we enrolled and randomly allocated 377 participants (188 [50%] to the EUC plus CAP group and 190 [50%] to the EUC alone group [one of whom was subsequently excluded because of a protocol violation]), of whom 336 (89%) completed the 3 month primary outcome assessment (164 [87%] in the EUC plus CAP group and 172 [91%] in the EUC alone group).\n\n The proportion with remission (59 [36%] of 164 in the EUC plus CAP group vs 44 [26%] of 172 in the EUC alone group; adjusted prevalence ratio 1·50 [95% CI 1·092·07]; p=0·01) and the proportion abstinent in the past 14 days (68 [42%] vs 31 [18%]; adjusted odds ratio 3·00 [1·765·13]; p&lt;0·0001) were significantly higher in the EUC plus CAP group than in the EUC alone group, but we noted no effect on mean daily alcohol consumed in the past 14 days among those who reported drinking in this period (37·0 g [SD 44·2] vs 31·0 g [27·8]; count ratio 1·08 [0·791·49]; p=0·62).\n\n We noted an effect on the percentage of days abstinent in the past 14 days (adjusted mean difference [AMD] 16·0% [8·124·1]; p&lt;0·0001), but no effect on the percentage of days of heavy drinking (AMD ?0·4% [5·7 to 4·9]; p=0·88), the effect of drinking (Short Inventory of Problems score AMD0·03 [1·93 to 1·86]; p=0.97), disability score (WHO Disability Assessment Schedule score AMD 0·62 [0·62 to 1·87]; p=0·32), days unable to work (no days unable to work adjusted odds ratio 1·02 [0·611·69]; p=0.95), suicide attempts (adjusted prevalence ratio 1·8 [2·4 to 6·0]; p=0·25), and intimate partner violence (adjusted prevalence ratio 3·0 [10·4 to 4·4]; p=0·57).\n\n The incremental cost per additional remission was $217 (95% CI 501073), with an 85% chance of being cost-effective in the study setting.\n\n We noted no significant difference in the number of serious adverse events between the two groups (six [4%] in the EUC plus CAP group vs 13 [8%] in the EUC alone group; p=0·11).\n\n\nInterpretation\nCAP delivered by lay counsellors plus EUC was better than EUC alone was for harmful drinkers in routine primary health-care settings, and might be cost-effective.\n\n CAP could be a key strategy to reduce the treatment gap for alcohol use disorders, one of the leading causes of the global burden among men worldwide.\n\n\nFunding\nWellcome Trust.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5236065","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Elsevier","authors":[{"firstname":"Abhijit","surname":"Nadkarni","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Benedict","surname":"Weobong","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Helen analysis employs mixed methods to explore the subjective mental health experience of participating in a 4- to 5-day photovoice process focused on climate change.\n A secondary objective of this work development of the Enhancing Assessment of Common Therapeutic factors (ENACT) rating scale","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1017/gmh.2015.21","date":"2015-10-25","title":"Development of a scoring system for non-specialist ratings of clinical competence in global mental health: a qualitative process evaluation of the Enhancing Assessment of Common Therapeutic Factors (ENACT) scale","abstract":"Background.\n\nTask-sharing is the involvement of non-specialist providers to deliver mental health services.\n\n A challenge for task-sharing programs is to achieve and maintain clinical competence of non-specialists, including primary care workers, paraprofessionals, and lay providers.\n\n We developed a tool for non-specialist peer ratings of common factors clinical competency to evaluate and optimize competence during training and supervision in global mental health task-sharing initiatives.\n\n\nMethods.\n\nThe 18-item ENhancing Assessment of Common Therapeutic factors (ENACT) tool was pilot-tested with non-specialists participating in mental health Gap Action Programme trainings in Nepal.\n\n Qualitative process evaluation was used to document development of the peer rating scoring system.\n\n Qualitative data included interviews with trainers and raters as well as transcripts of pre- and post-training observed structured clinical evaluations.\n\n\nResults.\n\nFive challenges for non-specialist peer ratings were identified through the process evaluation: (1) balance of training and supervision objectives with research objectives; (2) burden for peer raters due to number of scale items, number of response options, and use of behavioral counts; (3) capturing hierarchy of clinical skills; (4) objective v.\n\n subjective aspects of rating; and (5) social desirability when rating peers.\n\n\nConclusion.\n\nThe process culminated in five recommendations based on the key findings for the development of scales to be used by non-specialists for peer ratings in low-resource settings.\n\n Further research is needed to determine the ability of ENACT to capture the relationship of clinical competence with client outcomes and to explore the relevance of these recommendations for non-specialist peer ratings in high-resource settings.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5269630","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Cambridge University Press","authors":[{"firstname":"B. use in Nepal","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1471-244X-12-36","date":"2012-04-30","title":"Development and psychometric properties the Barriers to Access to Care Evaluation scale (BACE) related to people with mental ill health","abstract":"Background\nMany people with mental illness do not seek or delay seeking care.\n\n This study aimed to develop, and provide an initial validation of, a comprehensive measure for assessing barriers to access to mental health care including a treatment stigma subscale, and to present preliminary evidence about the prevalence of barriers experienced by adults currently or recently using secondary mental health services in the UK.\n\n\nMethods\nThe Barriers to Access to Care Evaluation scale (BACE) was developed from items in existing scales, systematic item reduction, and feedback from an expert group.\n\n It was completed in an online survey by 117 individuals aged 18 and over who had received care from secondary mental health services in the past 12 months.\n\n Internal consistency, test-retest reliability, convergent validity (correlation of treatment stigma subscale with the Stigma Scale for Receiving Psychological Help (SSRPH) and with the Internalised Stigma of Mental Illness Scale (ISMI)), respondent opinion and readability were assessed.\n\n\nResults\nThe BACE items were found to have acceptable test-retest reliability as all but one of the items exceeded the criterion for moderate agreement.\n\n The treatment stigma subscale had acceptable test-retest-reliability and good internal consistency.\n\n As hypothesised the subscale was significantly positively correlated with the SSRPH and the ISMI demonstrating convergent validity.\n\n The developmental process ensured content validity.\n\n Respondents gave the BACE a median rating of 8 on the 10-point quality scale.\n\n Readability scores indicated the measure can be understood by the average 11 to 12 year-old.\n\n The most highly endorsed barrier was concern that it might harm my chances when applying for jobs.\n\n The scale was finalised into a 30-item measure with a 12-item treatment stigma subscale.\n\n\nConclusions\nThere is preliminary evidence demonstrating the reliability, validity and acceptability of the BACE.\n\n It can be used to ascertain key barriers to access to mental health care which may help to identify potential interventions to increase care seeking and service use.\n\n Further research is needed to establish its factor analytic structure and population norms.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3379935","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed Williams JBW: The PHQ-9. J Gen Intern Med 2001, 16(9):606-613.","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12888-016-0768-y","date":"2016-03-01","title":"Detection of depression in low resource settings: validation of the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) and cultural concepts of distress in Nepal","abstract":"Background\nDespite recognition of the burden of disease due to mood disorders in low- and middle-income countries, there is a lack of consensus on best practices for detecting depression.\n\n Self-report screening tools, such as the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9), require modification for low literacy populations and to assure cultural and clinical validity.\n\n An alternative approach is to employ idioms of distress that are locally salient, but these are not synonymous with psychiatric categories.\n\n Therefore, our objectives were to evaluate the validity of the PHQ-9, assess the added value of using idioms of distress, and develop an algorithm for depression detection in primary care.\n\n\nMethods\nWe conducted a transcultural translation of the PHQ-9 in Nepal using qualitative methods to achieve semantic, content, technical, and criterion equivalence.\n\n Researchers administered the Nepali PHQ-9 to randomly selected patients in a rural primary health care center.\n\n Trained psychosocial counselors administered a validated Nepali depression module of the Composite International Diagnostic Interview (CIDI) to validate the Nepali PHQ-9. Patients were also assessed for local idioms of distress including heart-mind problems (Nepali, manko samasya).\n\n\nResults\nAmong 125 primary care patients, 17 (14 %) were positive for a major depressive episode in the prior 2 weeks based on CIDI administration.\n\n With a Nepali PHQ-9 cutoff???10: sensitivity?=?0.94, specificity?=?0.80, positive predictive value (PPV) =0.42, negative predictive value (NPV) =0.99, positive likelihood ratio?=?4.62, and negative likelihood ratio?=?0.07. For heart-mind problems: sensitivity?=?0.94, specificity?=?0.27, PPV?=?0.17, NPV?=?0.97. With an algorithm comprising two screening questions (1. presence of heart-mind problems and 2. function impairment due to heart-mind problems) to determine who should receive the full PHQ-9, the number of patients requiring administration of the PHQ-9 could be reduced by 50 %, PHQ-9 false positives would be reduced by 18 %, and 88 % of patients with depression would be correctly identified.\n\n\nConclusion\nCombining idioms of distress with a transculturally-translated depression screener increases efficiency and maintains accuracy for high levels of detection.\n\n The algorithm reduces the time needed for primary healthcare staff to verbally administer the tool for patients with limited literacy.\n\n The burden of false positives is comparable to rates in high-income countries and is a limitation for universal primary care screening.\n\n\nElectronic supplementary material\nThe online version of this article (doi:10.1186/s12888-016-0768-y) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4782581","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed Central","authors":[{"firstname":"Brandon A.","surname":"Kohrt","email":"brandon.kohrt@duke.edu","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Nagendra P.","surname":"Luitel","email":"luitelnp@gmail.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Prakash","surname":"Acharya","email":"pacharya07@gmail.com","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Prakash","surname":"Acharya","email":"pacharya07@gmail.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Mark J. D.","surname":"Jordans","email":"mark.jordans@kcl.ac.uk","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1093/alcalc/agt009","date":"2013-01-23","title":"Prevalence and Patterns of Hazardous and Harmful Alcohol Consumption Assessed Using the AUDIT among Bhutanese Refugees in Nepal","abstract":"Aims: This study sought to ascertain the prevalence of hazardous and harmful alcohol consumption among Bhutanese refugees in Nepal and to identify predictors of elevated risk in order to better understand intervention need.\n Methods: Hazardous and harmful alcohol consumption was assessed using the Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Test (AUDIT) administered in a face-to-face interview in a census of two camps comprising ?8000 refugees.\n Results: Approximately 1/5 men and 1/14 women drank alcohol and prevalence of hazardous drinking among current drinkers was high and comparable to that seen in Western countries with longstanding alcohol cultures.\n Harmful drinking was particularly associated with the use of other substances including tobacco.\n Conclusions: Assessment of the alcohol-related needs of Bhutanese refugees has permitted the design of interventions.\n This study adds to the Contact Coverage for Probable Depressive and Probable Alcohol Use Disorders in Four Low- and Middle-Income Country Districts: The PRIME Cross-Sectional Community Surveys","abstract":"Context\nA robust evidence base is now emerging that indicates that treatment for depression and alcohol use disorders (AUD) delivered in low and middle-income countries (LMIC) can be effective.\n\n However, the coverage of services for these conditions in most LMIC settings remains unknown.\n\n\nObjective\nTo describe the methods of a repeat cross-sectional survey to determine changes in treatment contact coverage for probable depression and for probable AUD in four LMIC districts, and to present the baseline findings regarding treatment contact coverage.\n\n\nMethods\nPopulation-based cross-sectional surveys with structured questionnaires, which included validated screening tools to identify probable cases.\n\n We defined contact coverage as being the proportion of cases who sought professional help in the past 12 months.\n\n\nSetting\nSodo District, Ethiopia; Sehore District, India; Chitwan District, Nepal; and Kamuli District, Uganda\nParticipants\n8036 adults residing in these districts between May 2013 and May 2014\nMain Outcome Measures\nTreatment contact coverage was defined as having sought care from a specialist, generalist, or other health care provider for symptoms related to depression or AUD.\n\n\nResults\nThe proportion of adults who screened positive for depression over the past 12 months ranged from 11.2% in Nepal to 29.7% in India and treatment contact coverage over the past 12 months ranged between 8.1% in Nepal to 23.5% in India.\n\n In Ethiopia, lifetime contact coverage for probable depression was 23.7%.\n\n The proportion of adults who screened positive for AUD over the past 12 months ranged from 1.7% in Uganda to 13.9% in Ethiopia and treatment contact coverage over the past 12 months ranged from 2.8% in India to 5.1% in Nepal.\n\n In Ethiopia, lifetime contact coverage for probable AUD was 13.1%.\n\n\nConclusions\nOur findings are consistent with and contribute to the limited evidence base which indicates low treatment contact coverage for depression and for AUD in LMIC.\n\n The planned follow up surveys will be used to estimate the change in contact coverage coinciding with the implementation of district-level mental health care plans.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5025033","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of Science","authors":[{"firstname":"Sujit alcohol use disorders identification test (AUDIT): validation of a Nepali version for the detection of alcohol use disorders and hazardous drinking in medical settings","abstract":"Background\nAlcohol problems are a major health issue in Nepal and remain under diagnosed.\n\n Increase in consumption are due to many factors, including advertising, pricing and availability, but accurate information is lacking on the prevalence of current alcohol use disorders.\n\n The AUDIT (Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Test) questionnaire developed by WHO identifies individuals along the full spectrum of alcohol misuse and hence provides an opportunity for early intervention in non-specialty settings.\n\n This study aims to validate a Nepali version of AUDIT among patients attending a university hospital and assess the prevalence of alcohol use disorders along the full spectrum of alcohol misuse.\n\n\nMethods\nThis cross-sectional study was conducted in patients attending the medicine out-patient department of a university hospital.\n\n DSM-IV diagnostic categories (alcohol abuse and alcohol dependence) were used as the gold standard to calculate the diagnostic parameters of the AUDIT.\n\n Hazardous drinking was defined as self reported consumption of ?21 standard drink units per week for males and ?14 standard drink units per week for females.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 1068 individuals successfully completed the study.\n\n According to DSM-IV, drinkers were classified as follows: No alcohol problem (n=562; 59.5%), alcohol abusers (n= 78; 8.3%) and alcohol dependent (n=304; 32.2%).\n\n The prevalence of hazardous drinker was 67.1%.\n\n The Nepali version of AUDIT is a reliable and valid screening tool to identify individuals with alcohol use disorders in the Nepalese population.\n\n AUDIT showed a good capacity to discriminate dependent patients (with AUDIT ?11 for both the gender) and hazardous drinkers (with AUDIT ?5 for males and ?4 for females).\n\n For alcohol dependence/abuse the cut off values was ?9 for both males and females.\n\n\nConclusion\nThe AUDIT questionnaire is a good screening instrument for detecting alcohol use disorders in patients attending a university hospital.\n\n This study also reveals a very high prevalence of alcohol use disorders in Nepal.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3508982","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1136/bmjopen-2016-013537","date":"2017-01-19","title":"Informing efficient randomised controlled trials: exploration of challenges in developing progression criteria for internal pilot studies","abstract":"Objectives\nDesigning studies with an internal pilot phase may optimise the use of pilot work to inform more efficient randomised controlled trials (RCTs).\n\n Careful selection of preagreed decision or progression criteria at the juncture between the internal pilot and main trial phases provides a valuable opportunity to evaluate the likely success of the main trial and optimise its design or, if necessary, to make the decision not to proceed with the main trial.\n\n Guidance on the appropriate selection and application of progression criteria is, however, lacking.\n\n This paper outlines the key issues to consider in the optimal development and review of operational progression criteria for RCTs with an internal pilot phase.\n\n\nDesign\nA structured literature review and exploration of stakeholders' opinions at a Medical Research Council (MRC) Hubs for Trials Methodology Research workshop.\n\n Key stakeholders included triallists, methodologists, statisticians and funders.\n\n\nResults\nThere is considerable variation in the use of progression criteria for RCTs with an internal pilot phase, although 3 common issues predominate: trial recruitment, protocol adherence and outcome data.\n\n Detailed and systematic reporting around the decision-making process for stopping, amending or proceeding to a main trial is uncommon, which may hamper understanding in the research community about the appropriate and optimal use of RCTs with an internal pilot phase.\n\n 10 top tips for the development, use and reporting of progression criteria for internal pilot studies are presented.\n\n\nConclusions\nSystematic and transparent reporting of the design, results and evaluation of internal pilot trials in the literature should be encouraged in order to facilitate understanding in the research community and to inform future trials.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5318608","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BMJ Publishing Group","authors":[{"firstname":"Kerry N checklist for clinical effectiveness pilot trials: a systematic approach","abstract":"Conducting a pilot trial is important in preparing for, and justifying investment in, the ensuing larger trial.\n Pilot trials using the same design and methods as the subsequent main trial are ethically and financially advantageous especially when pilot and main trial data can be pooled.\n For explanatory trials in which internal validity is paramount, there is little room for variation of methods between the pilot and main trial.\n For pragmatic trials, where generalisability or external validity is key, greater flexibility is written into trial protocols to allow for real life variation in procedures.\n We describe the development of a checklist for use in decision-making on whether pilot data can be carried forward to the main trial dataset without compromising trial integrity.\n We illustrate the use of the checklist using a pragmatic trial of psychosocial interventions for family carers of people with dementia as a case study.\n","id":"PMC3702517","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed health is to be effectively integrated into primary health care in low income countries like India then grass-roots workers need to acquire relevant knowledge and skills to be able to recognise, refer Karnataka, India, and to evaluate the impact of this training on mental health literacy.\n\n\nMethods\nA pre-test post-test study design was undertaken with assessment of mental health literacy at three time points; baseline, completion of the training, and three month follow-up.\n\n Mental health literacy was assessed using the interviewer-administered Mental Health Literacy Survey.\n\n The training intervention was a four day course based on a facilitator's manual developed specifically for community health workers in India.\n\n\nResults\n70 community health workers from Doddaballapur, Bangalore Rural District were recuited for the study.\n\n The training course improved participants' ability to recognize a mental disorder in a vignette, and reduced participants' faith in unhelpful and potentially harmful pharmacological interventions.\n\n There was evidence of a minor reduction in stigmatizing attitudes, and it was unclear if the training resulted in a change in participants' faith in recovery following treatment.\n\n\nConclusion\nThe findings from this study indicate that the training course demonstrated potential to be an effective way to improve some aspects of mental called for the integration of mental health into primary health care as a key strategy in closing the treatment gap.\n\n However, few studies in India have examined medical practitioners mental health-related knowledge and attitudes.\n\n This study examined these facets of service provision amongst doctors providing primary health care in a rural area of Karnataka is Southern India.\n\n\nMethods\nA mental health knowledge and attitudes questionnaire was self- administered by participants.\n\n The questionnaire consisted of four sections; 1) basic demographics and practice to their patients.\n\n However, there was a substantial level of endorsement for several statements that reflected negative attitudes.\n\n Almost one third of participants (28.0%) had not received any training in providing mental health care.\n\n Whilst three-quarters of participants correctly identified depression (76.1%) and psychosis (76.1%) in a vignette, fewer were able to name three common signs and symptoms of depression (50.0%) and psychosis (28.3%).\n\n\nConclusions\nIntegrating mental health into primary health care requires evidence-based up-skilling programs.\n\n Doctors in this stigma among community mental health staff in Guangzhou, China and in doing so also to assess the psychometric properties of the Reported and Intended Behaviour Scale (RIBS) - Chinese version.\n\n\nMethods\nA cross-sectional survey was undertaken among 214 community mental health staff in Guangzhou from September to November, 2013. The Mental Health Knowledge Schedule (MAKS) and RIBS were administered together with the Mental Illness: Clinicians Attitudes Scale (MICA) to evaluate staff stigma from the perspective of knowledge, attitudes and behaviour.\n\n\nResults\nThe total scores of RIBS, MAKS and MICA were (11.97?±?3.41), (16.80?±?5.39) and (51.69?±?6.94) respectively.\n\n Female staff members were more willing to contact people with mental illness than males (t(212)?=??2.85,P?=?0.005) and had more knowledge about mental illness (t(212)?=??2.28,P?=?0.024).\n\n The Chinese version of RIBS had good internal consistency (alpha?=?0.82), test-retest reliability (r?=?0.68,P?&lt;?0.001) and adequate convergent validity, as indicated by a significant negative correlation with the Chinese version of MICA(r?=??0.43, P?&lt;?0.001).\n\n\nConclusions\nOur results show relatively high levels of stigma toward people with mental illness among community mental health staff in Guangzhou, China.\n\n There are slightly gender differences in discriminatory behaviours and stigma related knowledge of mental illness among community mental health staff, with female staff in general less stigmatising.\n\n Accordingly, anti-stigma programmes should be established among healthcare staff.\n\n In addition, the Chinese version of RIBS is a reliable, valid and acceptable measure which can be used to assess the willingness of participants to contact people with mental illness in future anti-stigma campaigns.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4149249","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed
