found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0138066","date":"2015-08-25","title":"Effects of Combined Aerobic and Resistance Exercise on Exercise Capacity, Muscle Strength and Quality of Life in HIV-Infected Patients: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis","abstract":"Background\nMany HIV-infected patients demonstrate disability and lower aerobic capacity.\n\n The inclusion of resistance training combined with aerobic exercise in a single program is known as combined aerobic and resistance exercise (CARE) and seems to be an effective strategy to improve muscle weakness, as well as aerobic capacity in HIV-infected patients.\n\n We performed a meta-analysis to investigate the effects of CARE in HIV-infected patients.\n\n\nMethods\nWe searched MEDLINE, Cochrane Controlled Trials Register, EMBASE, CINAHL (from the earliest date available to august 2014) for controlled trials that evaluated the effects of CARE in HIV-infected patients.\n\n Weighted mean differences (WMD) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were calculated, and heterogeneity was assessed using the I2 test.\n\n\nResults\nSeven studies met the study criteria.\n\n CARE resulted in improvement in Peak VO2 WMD (4.48 mL·kg-1·min-1 95% CI: 2.95 to 6.0), muscle strength of the knee extensors WMD (25.06 Kg 95% CI: 10.46 to 39.66) and elbow flexors WMD (4.44 Kg 95% CI: 1.22 to 7.67) compared with no exercise group.\n\n The meta-analyses also showed significant improvement in Health status, Energy/Vitality and physical function domains of quality of life for participants in the CARE group compared with no exercise group.\n\n A nonsignificant improvement in social function domain of quality of life was found for participants in the CARE group compared with no exercise group.\n\n\nConclusions\nCombined aerobic and resistance exercise may improve peak VO2, muscle strength and health status, energy and physical function domains of quality of life and should be considered as a component of care of HIV-infected individuals.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4574781","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of HIV: an updated review of the literature","abstract":"Background\nAs infection with the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) has evolved to a chronic disease, perceived health-related quality of life (HRQoL) is becoming a prominent and important patient-reported outcome measure in HIV care.\n\n Literature discusses different factors influencing HRQoL in this population, however, currently no consensus exists about the main determinants.\n\n In this review a clear, up-to-date overview of the determinants influencing HRQOL among people living with HIV is provided.\n\n\nMethods\nAll studies published before July 2013 that identified determinants of HRQoL among people living with HIV in high-income countries, were considered in this narrative review.\n\n PubMed, Web of Science and The Cochrane Library were consulted using the keywords determinants, quality of life, HIV and AIDS.\n\n To be included, studies should have reported overall health and/or physical/mental health scores on a validated instrument and performed multivariable regression analyses to identify determinants that independently influence perceived HRQoL.\n\n\nResults\nIn total, 49 studies were included for further analysis and they used a variety of HRQoL instruments: Medical Outcomes Study Short Form-36 or variants, Medical Outcomes Study-HIV, HIV Cost and Services Utilization Study measure, Multidimensional Quality of Life Questionnaire, HIV targeted quality of life instrument, Functional Assessment of Human Immunodeficiency Virus Infection, HIV Overview of Problems Evaluation System, EuroQol, Fanning Quality of Life scale, Health Index and PROQOL-HIV.\n\n In this review, the discussed determinants were thematically divided into socio-demographic, clinical, psychological and behavioural factors.\n\n Employment, immunological status, presence of symptoms, depression, social support and adherence to antiretroviral therapy were most frequently and consistently reported to be associated with HRQoL among people living with HIV.\n\n\nConclusions\nHRQoL among people living with HIV is influenced by several determinants.\n\n These determinants independently, but simultaneously impact perceived HRQoL.\n\n Most HRQoL instruments do not capture all key determinants.\n\n We recommend that the choice for an instrument should depend on the purpose of the HRQoL assessment.\n\n\nElectronic supplementary material\nThe online version of this article (doi:10.1186/2049-3258-72-40) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized longitudinal observational study","abstract":"Background\nWhile studies have suggested that depression and HIV-related stigma may impede access to care, a growing body of literature also suggests that access to HIV care itself may help to decrease internalized HIV-related stigma and symptoms of depression in the general population of persons living with HIV.\n\n However, this has not been investigated in postpartum women living with HIV.\n\n Furthermore, linkage to care itself may have additional impacts on postpartum depression beyond the effects of antiretroviral therapy.\n\n We examined associations between linkage to HIV care, postpartum depression, and internalized stigma in a population with a high risk of depression: newly diagnosed HIV-positive pregnant women.\n\n\nMethods\nIn this prospective observational study, data were obtained from 135 HIV-positive women from eight antenatal clinics in the rural Nyanza Province of Kenya at their first antenatal visit (prior to testing HIV-positive for the first time) and subsequently at 6 weeks after giving birth.\n\n\nResults\nAt 6 weeks postpartum, women who had not linked to HIV care after testing positive at their first antenatal visit had higher levels of depression and internalized stigma, compared to women who had linked to care.\n\n Internalized stigma mediated the effect of linkage to care on depression.\n\n Furthermore, participants who had both linked to HIV care and initiated antiretroviral therapy reported the lowest levels of depressive symptoms.\n\n\nConclusions\nThese results provide further support for current efforts to ensure that women who are newly diagnosed with HIV during pregnancy become linked to HIV care as early as possible, with important benefits for found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0011213","date":"2010-05-28","title":"The Financial Burden of Morbidity in HIV-Infected Adults on Antiretroviral Therapy in Côte d'Ivoire","abstract":"Background\nLarge HIV care programs frequently subsidize antiretroviral (ARV) drugs and CD4 tests, but patients must often pay for other health-related drugs and services.\n\n We estimated the financial burden of health care for households with HIV-infected adults taking antiretroviral therapy (ART) in Côte d'Ivoire.\n\n\nMethodology/Principal Findings\nWe conducted a cross-sectional survey.\n\n After obtaining informed consent, we interviewed HIV-infected adults taking ART who had consecutively attended one of 18 HIV care facilities in Abidjan.\n\n We collected information on socioeconomic and medical characteristics.\n\n The main economic indicators were household capacity-to-pay (overall expenses minus food expenses), and health care expenditures.\n\n The primary outcome was the percentage of households confronted with catastrophic health expenditures (health expenditures were defined as catastrophic if they were greater than or equal to 40% of the capacity-to-pay).\n\n We recruited 1,190 adults.\n\n Median CD4 count was 187/mm3, median time on ART was 14 months, and 72% of subjects were women.\n\n Mean household capacity-to-pay was $213.7/month, mean health expenditures were $24.3/month, and 12.3% of households faced catastrophic health expenditures.\n\n Of the health expenditures, 75.3% were for the study subject (ARV drugs and CD4 tests, 24.6%; morbidity events diagnosis and treatment, 50.1%; transportation to HIV care centres, 25.3%) and 24.7% were for other household members.\n\n When we stratified by most recent CD4 count, morbidity events related expenses were significantly lower when subjects had higher CD4 counts.\n\n\nConclusions/Significance\nMany households in Côte d'Ivoire face catastrophic health expenditures that are not attributable to ARV drugs or routine follow-up tests.\n\n Innovative schemes should be developed to help HIV-infected patients on ART face the cost of morbidity events.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2887850","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of women in Malawi","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1007/s10461-013-0446-8","date":"1970-01-01","title":"HIV-related stigma as a barrier to achievement of Global PMTCT and maternal health goals: a review of the evidence","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0108150","date":"2014-08-25","title":"A Systematic Review of Health System Barriers and Enablers for Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) for HIV-Infected Pregnant and Postpartum Women","abstract":"Background\nDespite global progress in the fight to reduce maternal mortality, HIV-related maternal deaths remain persistently high, particularly in much of Africa.\n\n Lifelong antiretroviral therapy (ART) appears to be the most effective way to prevent these deaths, but the rates of three key outcomesART initiation, retention in care, and long-term ART adherenceremain low.\n\n This systematic review synthesized evidence on health systems factors affecting these outcomes in pregnant and postpartum women living with HIV.\n\n\nMethods\nSearches were conducted for studies addressing the population of interest (HIV-infected pregnant and postpartum women), the intervention of interest (ART), and the outcomes of interest (initiation, adherence, and retention).\n\n Quantitative and qualitative studies published in English since January 2008 were included.\n\n A four-stage narrative synthesis design was used to analyze findings.\n\n Review findings from 42 included studies were categorized according to five themes: 1) models of care, 2) service delivery, 3) resource constraints and governance challenges, 4) patient-health system engagement, and 5) maternal ART interventions.\n\n\nResults\nLow prioritization of maternal ART and persistent dropout along the maternal ART cascade were key findings.\n\n Service delivery barriers included poor communication and coordination among health system actors, poor clinical practices, and gaps in provider training.\n\n The few studies that assessed maternal ART interventions demonstrated the importance of multi-pronged, multi-leveled interventions.\n\n\nConclusions\nThere has been a lack of emphasis on the experiences, needs and vulnerabilities particular to HIV-infected pregnant and postpartum women.\n\n Supporting these women to successfully traverse the maternal ART cascade requires carefully designed and targeted interventions throughout the steps.\n\n Careful design of integrated service delivery models is of critical importance in this effort.\n\n Key knowledge gaps and research priorities were also identified, including definitions and indicators of adherence rates, and the importance of cumulative measures of dropout along the maternal ART Rural Kenya: Results from the MAMAS Study","abstract":"HIV/AIDS stigma is a common thread in the narratives of pregnant women affected by HIV/AIDS globally and may be associated with refusal of HIV testing.\n We conducted a cross-sectional study of women attending antenatal clinics in Kenya (N = 1525).\n Women completed an interview with measures of HIV/AIDS stigma and subsequently information on their acceptance of HIV testing was obtained from medical records.\n Associations of stigma measures with HIV testing refusal were examined using multivariate logistic regression.\n Rates of anticipated HIV/AIDS stigma were high32% anticipated break-up of their relationship, and 45% anticipated losing their friends.\n Women who anticipated male partner stigma were more than twice as likely to refuse HIV testing, after adjusting for other individual-level predictors (OR = 2.10, 95% CI: 1.153.85).\n This study demonstrated quantitatively that anticipations of HIV/AIDS stigma can instruments which have been validated in low and middle income countries: a systematic review","abstract":"Background\nGiven the high prevalence of depression in primary health care (PHC), the use of screening instruments has been recommended.\n\n Both brief and long depression screening instruments have been validated in low and middle income countries (LMIC), including within HIV care settings.\n\n However, it remains unknown whether the brief instruments validated in LMIC are as accurate as the long ones.\n\n\nMethods\nWe conducted a search of PUBMED, the COCHRANE library, AIDSLINE, and PSYCH-Info from their inception up to July 2011, for studies that validated depression screening instruments in LMIC.\n\n Data were extracted into tables and analyzed using RevMan 5.0 and STATA 11.2 for the presence of heterogeneity.\n\n\nResults\nNineteen studies met our inclusion criteria.\n\n The reported prevalence of depression in LMIC ranged from 11.1 to 53%.\n\n The area under curve (AUC) scores of the validated instruments ranged from 0.69-0.99. Brief as well as long screening instruments showed acceptable accuracy (AUC?0.7).\n\n Five of the 19 instruments were validated within HIV settings.\n\n There was statistically significant heterogeneity between the studies, and hence a meta-analysis could not be conducted to completion.\n\n Heterogeneity chi-squared = 189.23 (d.\n\nf.\n\n = 18) p&lt;.\n\n001.\nConclusion\nBrief depression screening instruments in both general and HIV-PHC are as accurate as the long ones.\n\n Brief scales may have an edge over the longer instruments since they can be administered in a much shorter time.\n\n However, because the ultra brief scales do not include the whole spectrum of depression symptoms including suicide, their use should be followed by a detailed diagnostic interview.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3534406","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed depression.\n\n\nDiscussion\nDepression is highly prevalent in Botswana, and its correlates are gender-specific.\n\n Our findings suggest multiple targets for screening and prevention of depression found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1136/sti.2008.033183","date":"2008-11-05","title":"Scaling up stigma? The effects of antiretroviral roll-out on stigma and HIV testing. Early evidence from rural Tanzania","abstract":"Objective:\nTo investigate the interplay between antiretroviral therapy (ART) scale-up, different types of stigma and Voluntary Counselling and Testing (VCT) uptake 2 years after the introduction of free ART in a rural ward of Tanzania.\n\n\nMethods:\nQualitative study using in-depth interviews and group activities with a purposive sample of 91 community leaders, 77 ART clients and 16 health providers.\n\n Data were analysed for recurrent themes using NVIVO-7 software.\n\n\nResults:\nThe complex interplay between ART, stigma and VCT in this setting is characterised by two powerful but opposing dynamics.\n\n The availability of effective treatment has transformed HIV into a manageable condition which is contributing to a reduction in self-stigma and is stimulating VCT uptake.\n\n However, this is counterbalanced by the persistence of blaming attitudes and emergence of new sources of stigma associated with ART provision.\n\n The general perception among community leaders was that as ART users regained health, they increasingly engaged in sexual relations and spread the disease.\n\n Fears were exacerbated because they were perceived to be very mobile and difficult to identify physically.\n\n Some leaders suggested giving ART recipients drugs for impotence, marking them with a sign and putting them in isolation camps.\n\n In this context, traditional beliefs about disease aetiology provided a less stigmatised explanation for HIV symptoms contributing to a situation of collective denial.\n\n\nConclusion:\nWhere anticipated stigma prevails, provision of antiretroviral drugs alone is unlikely to have sufficient impact on VCT uptake.\n\n Achieving widespread public health benefits of ART roll-out requires community-level interventions to ensure local acceptability of antiretroviral drugs.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2708343","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BMJ Group","authors":[{"firstname":"M","surname":"Roura","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"M","surname":"Urassa","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"J","surname":"Busza","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"D","surname":"Mbata","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"A","surname":"Wringe","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"B","surname":"Zaba","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1186/1472-698X-9-22","date":"2009-09-09","title":"'Just like fever': a qualitative study on the impact of antiretroviral provision on the normalisation of HIV in rural Tanzania and its implications for prevention","abstract":"Background\nOnce effective therapy for a previously untreatable condition is made available, a normalisation of the disease often occurs.\n\n As part of a broader initiative to monitor the implementation of the national antiretroviral therapy (ART) programme, this qualitative study investigated the impact of ART availability on perceptions of HIV in a rural ward of North Tanzania and its implications for prevention.\n\n\nMethods\nA mix of qualitative methods was used including semi-structured interviews with 53 ART clinic clients and service providers.\n\n Four group activities were conducted with persons living with HIV.\n\n Data were analyzed using the qualitative software package NVIVO-7.\nResults\nPeople on ART often reported feeling increasingly comfortable with their status reflecting a certain 'normalization' of the disease.\n\n This was attributed to seeing other people affected by HIV, regaining physical health, returning to productive activities and receiving emotional support from health service providers.\n\n Overcoming internalized feelings of shame facilitated disclosure of HIV status, helped to sustain treatment, and stimulated VCT uptake.\n\n However 'blaming' stigma - where people living with HIV were considered responsible for acquiring a 'moral disease' - persisted in the community and anticipating it was a key barrier to disclosure and VCT uptake.\n\n Attributing HIV symptoms to witchcraft seemed an effective mechanism to transfer 'blame' from the family unit to an external force but could lead to treatment interruption.\n\n\nConclusion\nAs long as an HIV diagnosis continues to have moral connotations, a de-stigmatisation of HIV paralleling that occurring with diseases like cancer is unlikely to occur.\n\n Maximizing synergies between HIV treatment and prevention requires an enabling environment for HIV status disclosure, treatment continuation, and safer sexual behaviours.\n\n Local leaders should be informed and sensitised and communities mobilised to address the blame-dimension of HIV stigma.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2759900","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed depression: validity and cultural dimensions","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0082521","date":"2013-10-22","title":"Reliability and Validity of Instruments for Assessing Perinatal Depression in African Settings: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis","abstract":"Background\nA major barrier to improving perinatal mental health in Africa is the lack of locally validated tools for identifying probable cases of perinatal depression or for measuring changes in depression symptom severity.\n\n We systematically reviewed the evidence on the reliability and validity of instruments to assess perinatal depression in African settings.\n\n\nMethods and Findings\nOf 1,027 records identified through searching 7 electronic databases, we reviewed 126 full-text reports.\n\n We included 25 unique studies, which were disseminated in 26 journal articles and 1 doctoral dissertation.\n\n These enrolled 12,544 women living in nine different North and sub-Saharan African countries.\n\n Only three studies (12%) used instruments developed specifically for use in a given cultural setting.\n\n Most studies provided evidence of criterion-related validity (20 [80%]) or reliability (15 [60%]), while fewer studies provided evidence of construct validity, content validity, or internal structure.\n\n The Edinburgh postnatal depression scale (EPDS), assessed in 16 studies (64%), was the most frequently used instrument in our sample.\n\n Ten studies estimated the internal consistency of the EPDS (median estimated coefficient alpha, 0.84; interquartile range, 0.71-0.87).\n\n For the 14 studies that estimated sensitivity and specificity for the EPDS, we constructed 2 x 2 tables for each cut-off score.\n\n Using a bivariate random-effects model, we estimated a pooled sensitivity of 0.94 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.68-0.99) and a pooled specificity of 0.77 (95% CI, 0.59-0.88) at a cut-off score of ?9, with higher cut-off scores yielding greater specificity at the cost of lower sensitivity.\n\n \nConclusions\nThe EPDS can reliably and validly measure perinatal depression symptom severity or screen for probable postnatal depression in African countries, but more validation studies on other instruments are needed.\n\n In addition, more qualitative research is needed to adequately characterize local understandings of perinatal depression-like syndromes in different African contexts.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3858316","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of Science","authors":[{"firstname":"Alexander 2":[]},{"doi":"10.1002/jia2.25167","date":"2018-07-06","title":"Power to participants: a call for person?centred <styled-content style='fixed-case'>HIV</styled-content> prevention services and research","abstract":"Introduction\nWhile biomedical HIV prevention offers promise for preventing new HIV infections, access to and uptake of these technologies remain unacceptably low in some settings.\n\n New models for delivery of HIV prevention are clearly needed.\n\n This commentary highlights the potential of person?centred programming and research for increasing the cultural relevance, applicability and use of efficacious HIV prevention strategies.\n\n It calls for a shift in perspective within HIV prevention programmes and research, whereby people are recognized for their agency rather than assumed to be passive beneficiaries or research participants.\n\n\nDiscussion\nPerson?centred HIV prevention reorientates power dynamics so that individuals (rather than interventions) are at the centre of the response.\n\n Respecting personal choice and agency  and understanding how these are shaped by the context in which people exercise these choices  are critical dimensions of the person?centred approach.\n\n Community?based participatory research should be employed to inform and evaluate person?centred HIV prevention.\n\n We argue that community?based participatory research is an orientation rather than a method, meaning that it can be integrated within a range of research methods including randomized controlled trials.\n\n But embracing community?based participatory approaches in HIV prevention research requires a systemic shift in how this type of research is reported in high impact journals and in how research impact is conceived.\n\n Community?based organizations have a critical role to play in both person?centred HIV prevention and research.\n\n\nConclusions\n\nHIV prevention is situated at the intersection of unprecedented opportunity and crisis.\n\n Person?centred approaches to HIV prevention and research shift power dynamics, and have the potential to ensure a more sustainable response with each individual actively participating in their own care and meaningfully contributing to the production of knowledge on HIV prevention.\n\n This approach taps into the resourcefulness, resilience and knowledge of the person and their communities, to strengthen research and programmes, making them more relevant, appropriate and effective.\n\n\n","id":"PMC6193315","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"John Wiley and Sons Inc.","authors":[{"firstname":"Marija","surname":"Pantelic","email":"mpantelic@aidsalliance.org","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Christine","surname":"Stegling","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sally","surname":"Shackleton","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Enrique","surname":"Restoy","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}],"References found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[],"References depth 2":[]},{"doi":"10.1007/s10461-011-9888-z","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Blame, Symbolic Stigma and HIV Misconceptions are Associated with Support for Coercive Measures in Urban India","abstract":"This study was designed to examine the prevalence of stigma and its underlying factors in two large Indian cities.\n Cross-sectional interview data were collected from 1,076 non-HIV patients in multiple healthcare settings in Mumbai and Bengaluru, India.\n The vast majority of participants supported mandatory testing for marginalized groups and coercive family policies for PLHA, stating that they deserved their infections and didnt care about infecting others.\n Most participants did not want to be treated at the same clinic or use the same utensils as PLHA and transmission misconceptions were common.\n Multiple linear regression showed that blame, transmission misconceptions, symbolic stigma and negative feelings toward PLHA were significantly associated with both stigma and discrimination.\n The results indicate an urgent need for continued stigma reduction efforts to reduce the suffering of PLHA and barriers to prevention and treatment.\n Given the high levels of blame and endorsement of coercive policies, it is crucial that such programs are shaped within a human rights framework.\n","id":"PMC3313036","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Springer US","authors":[{"firstname":"Maria found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1477-7517-5-28","date":"2008-08-23","title":"Stigma, social reciprocity and exclusion of HIV/AIDS patients with illicit drug histories: A study of Thai nurses' attitudes","abstract":"Background\nStigma is a key barrier for the delivery of care to patients living with HIV/AIDS (PLWHA).\n\n In the Asia region, the HIV/AIDS epidemic has disproportionately affected socially marginalised groups, in particular, injecting drug users.\n\n The effect of the stigmatising attitudes towards injecting drug users on perceptions of PLWHA within the health care contexts has not been thoroughly explored, and typically neglected in terms of stigma intervention.\n\n\nMethods\nSemi-structured interviews were conducted with a group of twenty Thai trainee and qualified nurses.\n\n Drawing upon the idea of 'social reciprocity', this paper examines the constructions of injecting drug users and PLWHA by a group of Thai nurses.\n\n Narratives were explored with a focus on how participants' views concerning the high-risk behaviour of injecting drug use might influence their attitudes towards PLWHA.\n\n\nResults\nThe analysis shows that active efforts were made by participants to separate their views of patients living with HIV/AIDS from injecting drug users.\n\n While the former were depicted as patients worthy of social support and inclusion, the latter were excluded on the basis that they were perceived as irresponsible 'social cheaters' who pose severe social and economic harm to the community.\n\n Absent in the narratives were references to wider socio-political and epidemiological factors related to drug use and needle sharing that expose injecting drug users to risk; these behaviours were constructed as individual choices, allowing HIV positive drug users to be blamed for their seropositive status.\n\n These attitudes could potentially have indirect negative implications on the nurses' opinions of patients living with HIV/AIDS more generally.\n\n\nConclusion\nDecreasing the stigma associated with illicit drugs might play crucial role in improving attitudes towards patients living with HIV/AIDS.\n\n Providing health workers with a broader understanding of risk behaviours and redirecting government injecting drug policy to harm reduction are discussed as some of the ways for stigma intervention to move forward.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2553400","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed Central","authors":[{"firstname":"Kit behavior prejudice among medical students in Southern China","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1471-2458-7-280","date":"2007-10-05","title":"Disentangling the stigma of HIV/AIDS from the stigmas of drugs use, commercial sex and commercial blood donation  a factorial survey of medical students in China","abstract":"Background\nHIV/AIDS related stigma interferes with the provision of appropriate care and support for people living with HIV/AIDS.\n\n Currently, programs to address the stigma approach it as if it occurs in isolation, separate from the co-stigmas related to the various modes of disease transmission including injection drug use (IDU) and commercial sex (CS).\n\n In order to develop better programs to address HIV/AIDS related stigma, the inter-relationship (or 'layering') between HIV/AIDS stigma and the co-stigmas needs to be better understood.\n\n This paper describes an experimental study for disentangling the layering of HIV/AIDS related stigmas.\n\n\nMethods\nThe study used a factorial survey design.\n\n 352 medical students from Guangzhou were presented with four random vignettes each describing a hypothetical male.\n\n The vignettes were identical except for the presence of a disease diagnosis (AIDS, leukaemia, or no disease) and a co-characteristic (IDU, CS, commercial blood donation (CBD), blood transfusion or no co-characteristic).\n\n After reading each vignette, participants completed a measure of social distance that assessed the level of stigmatising attitudes.\n\n\nResults\nBivariate and multivariable analyses revealed statistically significant levels of stigma associated with AIDS, IDU, CS and CBD.\n\n The layering of stigma was explored using a recently developed technique.\n\n Strong interactions between the stigmas of AIDS and the co-characteristics were also found.\n\n AIDS was significantly less stigmatising than IDU or CS.\n\n Critically, the stigma of AIDS in combination with either the stigmas of IDU or CS was significantly less than the stigma of IDU alone or CS alone.\n\n\nConclusion\nThe findings pose several surprising challenges to conventional beliefs about HIV/AIDS related stigma and stigma interventions that have focused exclusively on the disease stigma.\n\n Contrary to the belief that having a co-stigma would add to the intensity of stigma attached to people with HIV/AIDS, the findings indicate the presence of an illness might have a moderating effect on the stigma of certain co-characteristics like IDU.\n\n The strong interdependence between the stigmas of HIV/AIDS and the co-stigmas of IDU and CS suggest that reducing the co-stigmas should be an integral part of HIV/AIDS stigma intervention within this context.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2180176","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed Central","authors":[{"firstname":"Kit transmission and postnatal care for HIV-infected women and their children","abstract":"Background\nPrevention of mother-to-child transmission has been considered as not a simple intervention but a comprehensive set of interventions requiring capable health workers.\n\n Viet Nam's extensive health care system reaches the village level, but still HIV-infected mothers and children have received inadequate health care services for prevention of mother-to-child transmission.\n\n We report here the health workers' perceptions on factors that lead to their failure to give good quality prevention of mother-to-child transmission services.\n\n\nMethods\nSemistructured interviews with 53 health workers and unstructured observations in nine health facilities in Hanoi were conducted.\n\n Selection of respondents was based on their function, position and experience in the development or implementation of prevention of mother-to-child transmission policies/programmes.\n\n\nResults\nFactors that lead to health workers' failure to give good quality services for prevention of mother-to-child transmission include their own fear of HIV infection; lack of knowledge on HIV and counselling skills; or high workloads and lack of staff; unavailability of HIV testing at commune level; shortage of antiretroviral drugs; and lack of operational guidelines.\n\n A negative attitude during counselling and provision of care, treating in a separate area and avoidance of providing service at all were seen by health workers as the result of fear of being infected, as well as distrust towards almost all HIV-infected patients because of the prevailing association with antisocial behaviours.\n\n Additionally, the fragmentation of the health care system into specialized vertical pillars, including a vertical programme for HIV/AIDS, is a major obstacle to providing a continuum of care.\n\n\nConclusion\nMany hospital staff were not being able to provide good care or were even unwilling to provide appropriate care for HIV-positive pregnant women The study suggests that the quality of prevention of mother-to-child transmission service could be enhanced by improving communication and other skills of health workers, providing them with greater support and enhancing their motivation.\n\n Reduction of workload would also be important.\n\n Development of a practical strategy is needed to strengthen and adapt the referral system to meet the needs of patients.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2684067","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed Central","authors":[{"firstname":"Thu
